2582×582 235 KB  Hi everyone, thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Whether you hold MKR or DAI, own a vault, or want to get more involved in governance, this is your one-stop shop for MakerDAO updates. Authors: @alec, @nothsa, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon  Online PDF Version    What in the DAO is Going On?!    Halted Withdrawals on Lending Platforms Myriad lending protocols halted customer withdrawals last week, citing various reasons for the delays. Babel, Celsius, CoinFLEX, Hodlnaut, and Vauld are among the names closing up shop as the liquidity crunch, or “UST Contagion”, continues its spread. Click for more info on Celsius' wBTC-A position  With Celsius standing as one of Maker’s primary vault holders, their liquidity situation is the headline for our purposes. Collateral hadn’t been added to their wBTC-A position since June 16th, and its collateralization ratio dropped to a low of 154.1%. That changed on July 1st when the Celsius wallet began paying back DAI en masse.  Celsius deposits1462×482 127 KB  A frenzy of deposits totaling 196.7M upped vault collateralization to over 577.8%, decreasing its debt from ~202M DAI on July 1st to just over 82M DAI by the 4th.  Celsius de-risked1355×622 60.8 KB  Sidenote: In a room of the bad company, CoinFLEX still managed to stand out for its truly horrendous “risk management” practices.    Harmony Bridge Exploit Leads to the Theft of 6M DAI Damages: The Harmony Bridge held around $100M in wrapped assets, the entirety of which was drained, meaning every 1-wrapped token is currently un-backed. Click for more info on the hack and resulting DAI loss.  Harmony’s 2 of 5 multisig fell to a spearhead phishing campaign speculated to have been readied and performed by the Lazarus Group, the name was given to North Korea’s state-sponsored hacking force. The team reached out numerous times over the week via on-chain correspondence but received no response as the last of the funds made their way through Tornado Cash.  Not Lazarus’ first Rodeo  An FBI investigation identified that the methods used in the Ronin hack were eerily similar to attacks known to be carried out by the group, in which social engineering was utilized to gain access to company servers that contained the private keys used to sign legitimate network transactions. The Lazarus Group features two units with two distinct objectives:   BlueNorOff (APT-38, BeagleBoyz) is financially motivated sector hosting around 1,700 members. The sub-group primarily targets the SWIFT system and centralized and decentralized blockchain projects.  AndAriel (Andarial) focus lies on South Korean disruption. Not much is known about the sub-sector, but its targets have included everything from high-ranking Korean businessmen, to multi-national corporations, to government officials.   Potential Vectors for the Attack  Per a Twitter thread via Mudit Gupta, the heist falls in a string of similar “traditional hacks,” where the breaching of centralized servers, rather than an on-chain attack, led to the tremendous losses. Though full details have yet to be released, Gupta speculates that this central server was breached, warning developers that the next generation of mega-hacks won’t target chain-security but will come through more traditional vectors. He concludes that traditional security needs to be approached with the same vigor as chain-security.  What this means for Harmony  Harmony is functionally insolvent. Around $100M of its total $200M in locked value was housed on the Harmony Bridge. Without intervention, the chain is unlikely to recover. This figure may have dropped the hat a couple of months back, but with the VC landscape decimated, non-FTX/Alameda funding is tough to come by.  What this means for DAI  As multi-chain DeFi surged, many warned of centralized bridges’ risks. Risks which, unfortunately, made themselves abundantly clear this year. DAI played a minimal role in the Harmony ecosystem, but a number of wrapped derivatives were siphoned and laundered all the same. Around 6 million DAI were initially locked in the bridge contract. Today, less than ~9.5k remains. Sidenote: Massive props to the PE team for staying the course. The Optimism wormhole (and similar implementations) enables DAI to flourish without the systematic risks inherent to centralized bridging contracts. Last year, many feared DAI was falling behind the competition as various “stablecoins” quickly made their market presence known via shiny, new layer-1s. But rather than playing to the noise, PE stayed the course, positioning the DAO and DAI to benefit from the next wave of layer-2 innovation fully.   This Twitter thread talks about how a Crypto Stealer attack works and how to protect against it, and basic malware analysis.   Current Events   Delegate Office Hours  We are excited to introduce a new Delegate Office Hours call on Thursday, July 7th at 16:00 UTC! What started as a discussion by Tim Schuppener, Raphael Spannocchi, and others to help improve communication and coordination between delegates and core units has now become a public call named Delegate Office Hours. Thomas Flitter of Governance Communications will host the call. The format for this first call is simple; a kickoff discussion panel where each delegate has five minutes to speak on any topic of their choice, followed by an open mic section. Everyone is welcome to attend. Coming to a Calendar near you! Join Link - Zoom   DUX Updates - Fresh Off the Press!   Governance Portal Release v0.6.0  The DUX Core Unit team spent June delivering two primary new features: Gasless Poll Voting and Delegate Migration. The team also worked on improving the resiliency and efficiency of their tech infrastructure, especially needed after a recent increase in traffic and Delegate contracts. The research and architecture design phase for the Gasless Poll Voting feature has been finalized, and the finished product is set to launch in Q3 of this year. The system will be:  Fully compatible with Maker’s current voting system Free for the user Available to all MKR holders and delegates  The Delegate Migration feature, scheduled for launch in about two weeks, aims to streamline the migration process for expiring Delegate contracts, both for Recognized Delegates and for delegators.  Part 3 of the End-Game Summary by LongForWisdom  To aid his understanding and increase the accessibility of the ideas for everyone, @LongForWisdom posted a summary of Part 3 of @rune’s Endgame Plan. The structured, bullet-pointed summary:  Stresses the simplicity of the process Points out budget challenges as the primary area of concern Highlights the need for best practices to achieve a general separation of powers  MetaDAOs may be the best way to compartmentalize this risk   Introduces ideas around DAO2DAO operations  Follow @LongForWisdom’s Endgame Index List for a listing of Endgame-related posts and @LongForWisdom’s summaries.  A Unified DAO Toolkit to Help Make Transparency Easy  In this post, @rune argues that we should have “maximum reasonable transparency” regarding the work Core Units are engaging in. All significant work interactions between independent Core Units must be carried out publicly and thoroughly documented according to standardized procedures. @rune proposes a “unified DAO toolkit” to achieve this level of transparency. This kit would comprise a software tool used for workflow tracking, similar to Jira or Trello, and a wiki-like governance information dashboard. These two components combine governance and operations under a single system and allow for built-in transparency for “free.”  Risk Updates - Fresh Off the Press!  The Risk Core Unit was busy in June. Particular areas of interest are their work developing a multi-chain DAI liquidity strategy, an update to the Makerburn website, and continuing work on Maker Risk Dashboard v3. The team put out an in-depth post regarding why we need better DAI liquidity across blockchains and how we can achieve it. Ways to boost cross-chain DAI liquidity include:  Liquidity Incentives: A limited scope of incentives to bootstrap DAI liquidity on external domains to the point where DAI markets become self-sustainable. Partnerships: Hand in hand with self-funded incentives, Maker can partner with external protocols to support DAI liquidity and integration in their projects. Community Visibility: Independent community members and/or MKR whales don’t face the same governance and custody risks that MakerDAO itself would when deploying assets cross-chain. Hence, they could play an essential part in improving DAI liquidity across external domains.  The Makerburn website has new system surplus and estimate of annual profits pages.  The team recently made a post announcing v3 of the Maker Risk Dashboard.  For this third iteration, the team has:  Redesigned the website to provide a better and more accessible user experience Abstracted data, concepts, and models to reduce complexity and simplify the dashboard Added new features to provide access to data not previously available in v2     This Week in Governance   Weekly MIPs Update #94  Ratification polls, proposals, and pre-MIP discussions.  Executive Vote(s) Two executive votes passed this week, and the following changes occurred within the Maker Protocol:   MKR Vesting Transfers - June 22, 2022 – Passed on July 02, 2022, 13:03 UTC. Executed on July 04, 2022, 14:00 UTC.   Core Unit MKR Transfer and Advancing Collateral Offboardings - June 29, 2022 – Passed on June 29, 2022, 15:06 UTC. Executed on July 01, 2022, 16:40 UTC.    Core Unit MKR Vesting Transfers     Core Unit Amount Budget Proposal     Deco Fixed Rate (DECO-001) 500 MKR Budget Proposal   Real-World Finance (RWF-001) 152 MKR Budget Proposal   Risk Core Unit (RISK-001) 175 MKR Budget Proposal     Collateral Offboarding As per these successful polls for offboarding UNI-A, UNIV2DAIETH-A, UNIV2WBTCETH-A, UNIV2UNIETH-A, and UNIV2WBTCDAI-A, the following changes to liquidation parameters took place:     Parameter Vault Type + / - From / To     Liquidation Ratio UNI-A + 165% / 1300%   Liquidation Ratio UNIV2DAIETH-A + 120% / 2000%   Liquidation Ratio UNIV2WBTCETH-A + 145% / 2400%   Liquidation Ratio UNIV2WBTCDAI-A + 120% / 800%    The changes mentioned above will occur within 30 days. At the same time, the Flat Kick Incentive (tip), Liquidation Penalty (chop), and Debt Ceiling were set to 0 for all of these Collaterals. This executive vote follows a previously successful executive proposal, and it is the next step of performing collateral offboarding, as defined by MIP62. No changes to UNIV2UNIETH-A took place in this executive, as the vault-type already has 0 outstanding DAI. However, as this proposal passed, it will continue to be offboarded.  Governance Polls There are currently three active polls awaiting your participation:     Poll Name Discussion(s) Start Date End Date     Add RWA-009 (HVBank) as a new Vault Type  Initial Collateral Application / Real-World Finance Core Unit Risk Evaluation / Additional Risk Assessment - LOVE / Collateral Engineering Services Core Unit Evaluation / Oracles Core Unit Evaluation / HVB Transaction Documentation / RWA Foundation: HVB Disclosure / Delegated Committee Proposal  Jul 04, 2022, 16:00 UTC Jul 07, 2022, 16:00 UTC   PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Discussion Jul 04, 2022, 16:00 UTC Jul 07, 2022, 16:00 UTC   Select a Target Level of rNPI Profitability to Guide Budget Cuts Discussion Jul 04, 2022, 16:00 UTC Jul 07, 2022, 16:00 UTC     Prioritization Sentiment Polls These are the final results gathered after the first run of prioritization sentiment polls ended:     Prioritization Sentiment Vote Breakdown End Date     Technical Resource Deployment  Results852×774 24.1 KB  Jul 04, 2022 20:00 UTC   Collateral Class  Results852×606 21.6 KB  Jul 04, 2022 20:00 UTC     Community Greenlight Polls No greenlights this week, so this is it for Governance. Now, go vote!    Meetings and Events  Last Week’s Call Recordings:  Open Decentralized Voter Committee | June 29, 2022   Forum | Video Recording    Open Decentralized Voter Committee | June 30, 2022   Forum | Video Recording    Governance and Risk | Ep. 197   Forum | Video Recording    Focus On # 12: Centrifuge Indenture Trust Agreement Deep Dive   Forum | Video Recording     Upcoming Calls:  Avoiding the Tragedy: ACREinvest Delegate Office Hours | June 6 at 19:00 UTC   Forum | Join Link    Meet Your Delegate #16 - pvl | June 7 at 15:00 UTC   Forum | Join Link    Kickoff - Delegate Office Hours | June 7 at 16:00 UTC  Join Link    Recurring Calls:  Open Decentralized Voter Committee | Forum | Join Link - Wednesdays and Thursdays at 19:00 UTC  Governance & Risk Call | Join Link | Agenda - Thursdays at 17:00 UTC     Core Unit Office Hours   Join Link | GovAlpha Governance Q&As - Mondays at 17:00 UTC  Join Link | Immunefi Security - Every Other Monday at 23:00 UTC | Alternative Join Link - Every Other Wednesday at 15:00 UTC  Join Link | Protocol Engineering - Tuesdays at 15:00 UTC  Join Link | Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling - Tuesdays at 13:30 UTC  Join Link | Growth - First Wednesday of Each Month at 17:00 UTC  Join Link | Real World Finance - Every Other Wednesdays at 18:00 UTC  Join Link | Governance Communications - Fridays at 18:00 UTC  Join Link | 6S Capital - Every Other Wednesday at 14:00 UTC    Resources  Open List  All Available Dashboards   All Available Guides   Calls Calendar   Forum and Maker Discord   Governance Dashboard Tracker | Google Sheet Version   Know Your MIP Index   Learning Portal and Technical Documentation   MakerDAO’s Discord Servers   MakerBurn   Office Hours List   Participation Tools   Votes and Important Dates Calendar     Have Feedback? image2585×577 97.3 KB  Hi everyone, thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Whether you hold MKR or DAI, own a vault, or want to get more involved in governance, this is your one-stop-shop for MakerDAO updates. Authors: @alec, @nothsa, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon  Online PDF Version    What in the DAO is Going On?!    Aave proposes its own overcollateralized stablecoin, GHO While still in its polling stage, the announcement came from Aave Companies, the centralized entity that supports the protocol. Maker and Aave are lending protocols, but they’ve traditionally functioned under very different business models.  Through the Maker Protocol, users deposit assets to generate a set amount of DAI relative to the value of their deposit. Aave opted for the more traditional approach, where users deposit assets to earn interest. These deposits are then lent to borrowers at a premium.  Enter GHO, an overcollateralized stablecoin backed by myriad digital assets, which can only be minted against deposited collateral. If GHO is above peg, it’s profitable to mint it using another stablecoin and “short it” via stableswap pools. And if it dips below the peg? Paying back accrued debt is the most profitable path, allowing GHO’s total supply to contract as repaid debt is burned. All this, of course, sounds vaguely familiar… Put simply, GHO aims to position itself as a direct DAI competitor with near-identical tokenomics. Click for more info on the GHO proposal   What makes GHO any different? Yield. GHO minters would receive token rewards on both deposits and borrows, enabling a “double-sided” yield. These incentives are furthered through offering a discount on GHO to all users with stkAAVE locked into Aave’s Safety Module.  Aave Facilitators  Aave facilitators1600×800 95.9 KB  The proposal also introduced network “Facilitators,” i.e., protocols, entities, or institutions with the ability to ‘trustlessly’ generate GHO. Each Facilitator would be assigned a “bucket,” or an upward limit on the GHO they’re able to mint, and any party gunning for the designation must first be voted in through community governance. The Aave Protocol will activate as the genesis facilitator if the proposal passes.  Portals for cross-chain transfer Another interesting feature briefly described in the post is ‘Portals.’ These portals enable users to mint GHO on Ethereum to distribute across networks any number of networks. Portals would utilize ‘message passing’, in which a message (ex. sendTokenAndExecute()) moves along the source chain through ‘Gateways’ that confirm the call, subtract the minimum fee, and prepare the outgoing transaction on the destination chain. It’s then marked as approved and routed to the users’ desired chain. Also, the proposal leaves room for adding real-world assets (RWA) as the platform moves into direct financing. The service will also initially run on Aave v2, though an upgrade to v3 is expected in the coming weeks. To follow the discussion on the launch, head to this thread.    The Week’s Hottest Topic: Budget Reductions The majority of this week’s most trafficked threads can be boiled down to the singular point of budgetary concerns. With liquidity tightening, protocols have shifted to ‘survival mode,’ with many now re-considering the total sums of their expense sheets. As the recent discussion shows, Maker is no exception. Several concerns have been expressed, with some of the more pressing including:  Despite rapidly falling revenue, protocol expenses are still climbing as budget increases continue to pass. Fear of MKR dilution as vested tokens are divvied to contributors, the treasury surplus is drained. The need for a defined, streamlined budgeting process with several intended improvements, including:    Making it easier to compare different budgets and proposals The ability to alter budgets without excessive micromanagement Further convergence between assigned and utilized budgets     As discourse progressed, several proposals calling to alter or off-board particular CU budgets made their way to the forum. The most recent of these can be found here, with an attached post by @Ippy outlining a series of theoretical reforms meant to streamline the budgeting and compensation process. The entirety of the discussion and its ramifications can be followed via the ‘Current Events’ section below or through this megathread provided by @LongforWisdom.   Current Events  Anyone following the Maker forums knows how hotly debated the topic of budgeting has been in recent months, and the past week was no exception. Today, we propose revamping Delegate compensation, instituting fire drills to test Delegates’ emergency preparedness, and more.  Restructuring Incentives for Recognized Delegate Compensation  @aburban90 of the Strategic Happiness Core Unit believes that while it makes sense to compensate Recognized Delegates for the difficult task of voting effectively on every proposal, the current incentive structure is not well designed. In this post, he offers several new mechanisms he believes will improve the way. Delegate compensation works at MakerDAO. Weighting for Community Presence Weight Factor: Up to 30% Because a longer track record with Maker may indicate a deeper understanding of Maker’s foundational values and core principles, this mechanism would compensate Delegates more the longer they’ve been community members. A simple way to measure this factor is to check when a Delegate’s first activity on the forums took place. Whale Backer Registry If a single source backs a large percentage of a Delegate’s MKR, this information should be clearly transparent and publicly available. Skin In The Game Weight Factor: Depends on the Amount of Staked MKR This mechanism would require all Delegates to stake some of their own MKR as collateral before being eligible for any Delegate compensation. Some of this staked MKR could be slashed or burned when a Delegate is not effectively carrying out their duties. Compensation in MKR Delegates are compensated using DAI from the Surplus Buffer. @aburban90 would like to see Delegates compensated using a combination of DAI and MKR, redirecting some of the DAI taken from the Surplus Buffer to purchase MKR, which can then be added to the Delegate’s voting power and vested. If a Delegate resigns, purchased but not distributed, MKR can be burned. According to the informal poll results, forum readers support compensating Delegates in MKR in addition to DAI and requiring Delegates to disclose whale-supported MKR backing.  Fire drill, Request for Discussion + Informal Polls  Part of the Immunefi Security Core Unit’s mandate is the performance of “fire drills”—practice events aimed at answering the question “How long would it take to pass an unexpected, unannounced emergency executive spell?” The first fire drill was set to take place in February but was delayed due to the lack of a clear idea of what a fire drill should include. In this post, @psychonaut proposes the following process:  A fire drill will be declared every month at a random day and time. Delegates will be asked via emergency communication channels to sign a message. Reaction time will be measured and recorded.  Potential benefits include:  Regular testing of Delegates’ emergency preparedness Reaction times displayed on Delegates’ information pages, adding another metric for MKR holders to consider when delegating their voting power Reaction times could be incorporated into the Delegate compensation structure   CU Budget Reduction Initiatives - A Wiki Summary  This post by @LongForWisdom aims to gather budget-related initiatives, both Maker-wide and at the individual Core Unit level, in one place as a reference point for the community. This wiki post is freely editable by forum users with trust level 3 or higher @LongForWisdom has asked forum-goers well acquainted with the ongoing budgeting debates to contribute to the document.  pLaP59r636×888 86 KB   Endgame DVC Meeting - July 20 | Budget reductions and growth/marketing CU consolidations  @rune has announced his intention for the Endgame Decentralized Voter Committee meeting on Wednesday, July 20th at 7 pm UTC to focus on budget reduction plans. His approach involves streamlining Core Unit budgets by identifying the “low hanging fruit where budgets can be reduced” and then consolidating similar Core Units with unified budgets. @rune hopes that after gaining some clarity on budget questions, preliminary MKR voter support for an overall direction for future budget reductions and consolidations can be achieved, enabling Core Units “to focus on their day-to-day more and not worry about sudden top-down budget changes.”     Help Wanted! Andrew Burban of Strategic Happiness Core Unit asks for community help distributing Maker swag to EthCC in Paris. If anyone attending EthCC lives near New York or Washington D.C. and has some available baggage space, please, contact @aburban90 by July 14. Executive Vote(s) A tripartite executive vote passed this week, and the following changes occurred within the Maker Protocol:   Core Unit Distributions, Recognized Delegate Compensation, Keeper Network Stream Setup - July 06, 2022 – Passed on July 06, 2022, 23:32 UTC. A suspicious poll appeared on the Voting Portal on July 08, 2022. It was later revealed on the Forum by @Prose11 that this was a fire drill to gauge celerity in response, with almost no previous notice to the community, to a malicious attack.  A fraction of the voting power shown in this breakdown reflects the voter’s opinions on the drill’s usefulness, although this test was not conceived as a means to evaluate that in the beginning. Suppose you wish to voice your opinion on this matter. In that case, there is currently a poll in the original thread aiming to effectively assess the community’s sentiment in that regard: Is monthly a good frequency? 2587×582 102 KB  Hi everyone, thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Whether you hold MKR or DAI, own a vault, or want to get more involved in governance, this is your one-stop-shop for MakerDAO updates. Authors: @alec, @nothsa, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon  Online PDF Version    CURRENT EVENTS    Ongoing Offboarding Proposals Three proposals have now been posted to offboard and remove various Core Units. As such, this made for a natural topic of discussion during this week’s Delegate Office Hours. The discussion began with IS-001, represented by its facilitator, @psychonaut. Several options for compromise were presented and will be covered below. But first, it’s worth noting that IS-001 first proposed these reductions in its June update before the proposal to offboard surfaced. As such, several delegates applauded IS-001 for its proactivity and feel the proposed changes offer a template for other facilitators to fix perceived issues before drastic measures are taken. IS-001’s Proposed Reduction   A reduction of the current minimum monthly spend from 22k to 8k Payments to Immunefi drop from 10k monthly to 0 A reconsidering of active partnerships with Chaos Labs and DeFi Safety.   Note: An Immunefi budget cut would immediately cease report triaging, educational content, reports on non-critical vulnerabilities, as well as access to their war room/emergency response service. Further, IS-001 views Chaos Labs as an integral part of the future of the bug bounty program. Currently, whitehats don’t have the incentive to spin up the proper environments to test and push the protocol. Chaos Labs enables this environment to be quickly installed, meaning additional eyes on the code and additional conditions being tested that might not have been considered. The conversation then broadened, and a few underlying problems were identified. First, we have three offboarding proposals running concurrently, but the MIP to revise this process has yet to go through. @twblack88 feels we need to start viewing these proposals through the lens of this new framework, which emphasizes working alongside CUs directly to encourage proactivity. The second was best put by @rspa.  “We want to see budgetary discipline, but we haven’t established what that really means.”  To him, this means allocating budgets to the “right things,” but we first need to establish a basis for deciding what the “right things” are. Before we continue down this path, a central strategy needs to be agreed upon, granting CUs a more detailed path to success and ensuring that various CU initiatives align under that message. The third served as more of a subtle reminder. @schuppi warns that while forum activity in no way dictates a majority opinion amongst MKR holders, from the outside looking in, it very much appears that way. An idea expounded on by @Thomas-flitter1. The Events CU was added very recently, delivered on the items laid out in their roadmap, and is still under fire due to market conditions. Put simply; they haven’t been given enough time, particularly when they were indeed operating via the strategy that saw them ratified. To conclude, there’s more work that needs to be done, but frameworks offering solutions to some of these issues are already in the works. All that said, based on the week’s discussion, talks surrounding a DAO-wide strategy are sure to follow. Click here to watch the discussion in full. 2587×577 105 KB  Hi everyone, thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Authors: @alec, @nothsa, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon  Online PDF Version     CURRENT EVENTS    Budgeting for Bear Markets Bear markets are always bleak, but ‘bleak’ is an ever-shifting point of reference. For many, the current macro-economic landscape represents that fresh perspective. As such, much of the week’s discussion focused on long-term profitability, with a wide range of posts and discussion calls centered around budgetary management. Some of these proposed solutions could see short-term ramifications, but they aim to position the DAO for the long term better. The most recent MakerDAO DVC Meeting discussed these concerns in detail. A written version of the signal, posted by @pipko of the Risk CU, and its ensuing discussion can be found in this thread. …   Summary of the Risk CU’s Budget Re-allocation Signal  “[The protocol is] well capitalized with a return to profitability in sight, but cost structure must be reassessed.”  Current Financial Position  The DAO incurred no ‘bad debt’ linked to key CeFi lenders despite significant initial exposure. Over a 1-month window that began on May 1, non-stable collateral fell from USD 3.3B to USD 1.2B, resulting in USD 11.3M in liquidation income. As of July 22, only 1.02B in non-stable collateral remains locked in the protocol, meaning the DAO can no longer rely on consistent liquidation income as a significant source of profit.  Forecasted Revenue & Cash Flow  The Protocol operates at a monthly loss of USD 2M until balance sheet assets are deployed into short-term treasury bonds. Without further deterioration in the crypto lending markets, Maker will break even by Q1 2023.  Paths Forward Of the two proposed options, the Risk CU prefers ‘Option 2’ but will support any solution chosen by the DAO and MKR holders. That said, given their preference, the “Tactical Re-Allocation” option is more fleshed out in theory and form. As such, Option 2 will focus on this summary.  Risk's proposed paths forward934×495 286 KB  Per Risk’s assessment, this approach enables token holders to allocate capital based on merit and granted holistically under a DAO-wide view. The framework aims to address myriad issues seen in the status quo, particularly surrounding:   Transparency into CU activities and initiatives; difficulties surrounding performance evaluation, and; non-simultaneous budgeting periods.   …  Proposed Budgeting Process Note that each stage of this proposed process would be executed concurrently across all existing and proposed core units.  1458×797 102 KB  1. Core unit Budget & KPI Proposals  Delegates and MKR holders would determine the ‘Targeted Spend’ level for the budgeting period through an on-chain vote. CUs propose budgets, layout key operating activities, strategic goals, and KPIs, and highlight capital tradeoffs in a “low/high” budget allocation scenario. As part of this process, CUs promise to deliver operating results (in the form of KPIs) in return for a capital allocation from the DAO. As such, core units should identify and release operational KPIs that accurately reflect the impact and return their services offer the protocol. Delegates and MKR holders would then assist core units with developing, negotiating, and measuring KPIs to confirm that the targets set are reasonable for both the unit and the protocol.  2. Budget Proposal Evaluation With the help of delegates and MKR holders, several competing budget iterations would be drafted and polled. The general flow would track as follows:  Delegates and MKR holders vote in an on-chain ranked choice poll on the competing budget plans presented, excluding proposals that do not meet the agreed upon ‘Target Spend.’ After a ranked choice poll is selected, the winning budget plan is proposed to an on-chain binary vote.  3. Capital Allocation & KPI Re-Targeting After on-chain confirmation, CU Facilitators would be expected to communicate the perceived impact that both “lower and higher” capital allocations would impact their KPIs, and new operational promises would be established. 4. Evaluation of KPI attainment Once the KPI period is complete, the delegates and MKR holders will review each core unit’s KPI scorecard to understand how they performed against their strategic goals. Once KPI attainment can be condensed into a qualitative metric, Delegates and MKR holders would have the information necessary to make informed decisions moving forward. The post ends with a Signal Request meant to gauge community sentiment on the proposed options. Option 2: Tactical Reallocation has currently captured 48% of the total votes.  image1700×922 160 KB  Note that due to the urgency triggered by market conditions, this signal will run for one week and is set to end on July 30th. Delegate contracts, through which delegators delegate their MKR voting power to delegates, expire after one year. Because of this, delegates and their delegators need to migrate to a new contract once the old one expires to ensure that delegated MKR intended to be activated in governance operations does not go “stale.” To facilitate this process, the Governance Portal UI now displays a banner letting both delegates and their delegators know when their existing delegate contract is expiring and offering guidance through the migration process.  979×727 204 KB    Request for feedback - legal work for MakerDAO  @Balloonist, a member of SES’s currently incubating Legal Research Team, has put together a document intended to serve as a go-to resource for answering legal and other questions: “a Stack Overflow-like database for DAO and DeFi problems and solutions.” Balloonist envisions the document potentially becoming broader in scope and encompassing contributions from members of other DAOs to help define and refine problems and offer broadly applicable solutions.  1343×536 75.7 KB    Codeknight Delegate Platform   My goal is to turn Maker into a trillion-dollar entity that is easy to understand and decentralized. 2585×572 117 KB  Hi everyone, thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Whether you hold MKR or DAI, own a vault, or want to get more involved in governance, this is your one-stop-shop for MakerDAO updates. Authors: @alec, @nothsa, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon  Online PDF Version    CURRENT EVENTS   MIP-6 Declaration of Intent – Invest in short-term bonds – Proposal for implementation  @backed-finance presents a Collateral Onboarding application for tokenized, short-term Treasury bonds held under Swiss law. The proposal points to MIP13c3-SP12, which ratified a ‘Declaration of Intent’ for the DAO to invest in such bonds. Under the proposed terms, Backed Finance would create “on-chain, permissionless securities backed 1:1 with an underlying, short-term bond ETF” to be held by a secure, third-party custodian in Switzerland. Market participants would then sell these tokenized bonds to the DAO. The preliminary concept (subject to RFC) would utilize a “modified PSM implementation,” incentivizing market participants to sell tokenized ETFs in exchange for newly minted DAI. Per the MIP, all trading would be liquid, permissionless, and require no active management or KYC on the part of the protocol.  Summary of the proposed asset ⮛  Token: Backed iShares $ Treasury Bond 1-3yr UCTIS ETF (Accumulating) Contract Address: 0x9ABB4E7f4ee96cA58F156338640aEd031188E5E1   Its subsidiary, Backed Assets, would tokenize IBTA (USD denominated Treasury bonds) securities on the Ethereum chain, granting the protocol access to passive revenue in a “fully permissionless way.” The asset is "fully backed by the linked underlying. The token is an ERC-20, entitling its holders to the right to redeem it for fiat through the issuer at any time (during standard business hours). The token is a new issuance and would begin with a circulating supply of zero on-chain. As the asset is an ERC-20, transactions would also be settled on-chain.  Note: As the underlying is conventional security, it’s inherently based on a trusted system, which operates as follows: The underlying capital is purchased through a Broker and placed in a custody account. This custody account is then supervised by an unrelated third party (referred to as the “Security Agent”), who has the authority to “block the account and liquidate assets to repay holders the value of their investment.”  Current Custodian: ISP Securities AG, Zurich, Switzerland Current Security Agent: Security Agent Services AG, Baarerstrasse 75, 6300 Zug, Switzerland   Summary of Proposed Use Cases ⮛  The DAI generated through this vault would be distributed to its depositors at a slight spread. Following oracle price updates, “the price change should mint new DAI directly into the surplus buffer.” The vault’s Debt Ceiling would be calculated as a percentage of the DAO’s stablecoin holdings to allow the volume to shift toward the proposed ETF token. Backed Finance proposes an initial Debt Ceiling of $50M.   Given the potential of the proposal, its generated quite a bit of discussion. If you’re looking to weigh in or follow the debate, the post can be found here.   Delegate Participation & Compensation  Four delegation-centric proposals made their way to the Forums last week. GovAlpha Facilitator, @Patrick_J, posted three frameworks to define and streamline the process for delegate participation and compensation. The fourth, via @GFXlabs, proposes an amendment period for Recognized Delegate participation metrics. MIP-77: Delegates in the Maker Protocol aims to establish a baseline definition of the Recognized Delegate role and provide a framework, or “foundational MIP,” upon which future iterations can be implemented.  Summary of Roles & Responsibilities ⮛ Per the proposal, the role of a Recognized Delegate can be broken down into two parts:   To express an opinion on on-chain Governance processes by casting regular votes. To communicate their voting decisions and the rationale behind them.   Beyond this, Recognized Delegates may take on additional roles and responsibilities as they see fit.  Summary of Participation & Communication Metrics ⮛ Recognized Delegates are expected to vote on Executive Proposals or voice their explicit opposition within 72 hours of their posting. Failing to vote for an Executive would not count against a Recognized Delegate’s participation metrics if sound reasoning for the absence is provided (as assessed by Governance Facilitators). Further, Recognized Delegates would be expected to communicate their vote within seven days of a Governance Poll’s conclusion.  Summary of Regonized Delegate Metric Reset ⮛ Under the proposed framework, a Recognized Delegate could request a reset of their tracked metrics if approved by a majority of Governance Facilitators. If approved, a Recognized Delegate may choose any date within the last three months as the new “start date” for tracking personal metrics. These requests could only be made once per year. MIP-78: Recognized Delegate DAI Compensation seeks to define the DAO’s process for awarding DAI compensation to Recognized Delegates. The Maker Protocol compensates Recognized Delegates to incentivize their participation in the system of governance. In return, the Protocol receives a diverse group of individuals capable and incentivized to study proposals, cast votes, and communicate their reasoning to a public forum.  Summary of MIP-78’s Proposed Goals ⮛  DAI compensation should positively correlate to voting weight. One Recognized Delegate’s compensation should be independent of another’s compensation. This compensation would be positively skewed toward Recognized Delegates with smaller voting weight to encourage the recruitment of new Recognized Delegates. A cap on the maximum DAI compensation a single delegate can receive should be imposed. Recognized Delegates with high voting weights should receive enough compensation from having the option to hire an assistant(s). The system should allow for and appropriately compensate Recognized Delegates acting as part of a team or group.   Initial Parameters if Ratified ⮛  MIP-79: Recognized Delegate MKR Compensation shares a similar goal as the above but is geared toward the growth and retention of talented Recognized Delegates. The proposed system aims to encourage a “longer-term” mindset that would more fully align Recognized Delegates with the MKR holders that delegate to them. If the MIP passes as proposed, MKR will be distributed to Recognized Delegates using DssVest to an address of their choice. Streams must have a twelve-month duration and a cliff date of twelve months. Governance Facilitators will post the amount of MKR to be streamed, stream dates, and cliff dates to the Maker Governance Forum in advance of the relevant Executive Vote.  How would vesting be calculated? ⮛  "Once a Recognized Delegate has been active for six months, in effect, six months since they completed the steps to become a Recognized Delegate defined in MIP77c2 and received their first delegated MKR tokens, the Governance Facilitators will calculate the total DAI compensation the Recognized Delegate has received in that time. This value will be divided by the 12-month rolling average price of the MKR token in DAI. This will calculate the amount of MKR vesting to which the Recognized Delegate is entitled."  MIP4c2-SP24: Amend Measurement Period For Delegate Participation Metrics proposes to amend the feedback loop for delegate participation, which is a key variable in the calculation of their compensation. If passed, the proposal would amend the language ratified in MIP61c2. The proposed alterations can be found here.   Clarifications about my take on LOVE vs. MetaDAO and a diagram of approval voting   With a set of broadly supported core system delegates, we can start untangling this mess without every single vote being split down the middle based on essentially political lines.  MakerDAO co-founder @nikolai clarified his views on the LOVE and MetaDAO proposals. In short: “I am not in favor of the MetaDAO proposal any more than I am in favor of the LOVE proposal.” Nikolai believes that Maker governance is largely split down the middle, resulting in contentious vote after contentious vote and a roster of Delegates lacking broad support due to the current simple majority voting system. He argues that before making any severe changes to the governance system, Maker needs to address this “dysfunctional” governance situation by reducing complexity and clarifying how the current voting system works. 2585×575 110 KB  Hi everyone, thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Whether you hold MKR or DAI, own a vault, or want to get more involved in governance, this is your one-stop shop for MakerDAO updates. Authors: @alec, @nothsa, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon  Online PDF Version     CURRENT EVENTS   Tornado Cash Sanctions  We finally reached that subtle paradigm shift, where the line between human and machine begins to blur. Smart contracts can now be sanctioned as if they were sentient. In a press release distributed on August 8th by the Department of the Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC), the popular mixing service, Tornado Cash and its contracts heard the gavel fall. In an unprecedented move, OFAC designated the smart contracts as  Specially Designated Nationals - a classification typically reserved for nation-states and terrorist organizations. Tornado Cash and its IP were designated under EO. 13694, an Executive Order enabling the blocking of property and assets of individuals engaged in malicious online activity. Per the report: ⮟  Tornado Cash has been used to launder over $7 billion since its 2019 inception. Of that total, at least $455 million was stolen by the Lazarus Group - North Korea’s state-sponsored hacking arm. We’ve already seen 96 million USD stolen and laundered from the Harmony ONE bridge heist and at least 7.8 million USD via the Nomad exploit in 2022.  Results of the imposed sanctions: ⮟  All properties and IP associated with Tornado Cash in the United States are blocked and must be reported to OFAC. Any entities owned directly or indirectly by “one or more blocked persons” will also be blocked. All transactions by U.S.-centered blockees involving the sanctioned assets are prohibited without a specific license issued by OFAC.  Surprisingly, the news wasn’t well received, and several high-profile crypto-natives have now levied their two cents on the implications of the imposed sanctions. Among these was @Rune, who shared his views in a recent interview with Coindesk. He feels the sanctions are counter-productive, even bordering on pointless. Due to the nature of open-source software, it’s a simple procedure to redeploy an identical protocol.  “Target the criminals you actually want to target.”  If the goal is to utilize a “blacklisting” procedure on state-sponsored hacking groups, shutting down the infrastructure won’t accomplish it. Instead, known North-Korean Ethereum wallets should be actively monitored, allowing for stolen assets to be frozen the moment they enter these wallets. Rune ends with a warning that blanket bans like these only serve to stifle innovation that can truly benefit the average consumer. But as it goes, the effects of the sanctions didn’t stop with Tornado Cash. The report only mentioned mixing services directly, but some view Tornado as the first of many dominos to fall. Aave responded by blocking all addresses that had interfaced with Tornado Cash from its front-end. Furthermore, per a tweet via banteg - they certainly aren’t alone in their efforts.   twitter.com    banteg @bantg  when defi apps started snitching on you, with links  2021-10-25 uniswap github.com/Uniswap/interf… 2022-05-10 ren github.com/renproject/bri… 2022-06-29 balancer github.com/balancer-labs/… 2022-08-11 oasis github.com/OasisDEX/oasis… 2022-08-12 aave github.com/aave/interface… (never) yearn, curve https://t.co/1FkgVPnUqb   11:52 PM - 12 Aug 2022           1.1K                270            Links are provided to the Github pages of Uniswap, Ren, Balancer, Oasis, and Aave, highlighting the moments “when DeFi apps started snitching on you.” An ongoing discussion centered around the sanctions, as well as the suspected arrest of a Tornado Cash developer, can be found here.  A ‘Project-Based Budgeting’ Proposal  @juan of SES-001 outlined his ideas for a new method of budget distribution. The proposal views the current structure as imbalanced, with the “Workforce” maintaining full control over the work being done, as well as its prioritization. A summary of the proposed changes: ⮟ Currently MKR holders:  Must accept or reject the whole deal, are unable to provide direction; and find themselves discussing people rather than work.  If polled as proposed, a CU would propose any number of projects with all expenses attached. A general budget would then be assigned, and these projects would be voted on and ranked via on-chain Governance.  High-level Roadmap of Proposal1974×1110 184 KB  Any projects that fall within the assigned budget limit receive funding. Those that remain would be discarded. This implementation provides two primary advantages: ⮟  It grants MKR holders the means to choose the projects they want to see built. Currently, budgetary proposals trend toward a Core Unit vs. MKR holder mentality. The proposed model encourages productive discussion surrounding the merits of individual projects, thus decreasing the friction inherent to an “all-or-nothing” approach.  A link to the proposal and its ensuing discussion can be found here.  Monthly Financial Reporting | July 2022  @adcv of SF-001 provides an updated look into the DAO’s current and forecasted financials. The full slide deck can be found here. A summary of the report: ⮟  710×278 14.1 KB   The post highlights these topics as priorities for community consideration:  [SIGNAL REQUEST] N6M Target Spend Level Lower ETH/WBTC stability fees to reduce USDC reliance and attract more borrowers URGENT: Signal Request Set Aave D3M bar to 0% [GUNIV3-BUSD-DAI] MIP6 Collateral Onboarding Application Form Ratification Poll for Makershire Redux (MIP76) - August 8, 2022  SF-001 concludes with a Dune query that includes all relevant wallet addresses and their current standing.    A link to the full report and its ensuing discussion can be found here.    Governance Voting and Delegation Compensation   MIPX: Maker Compensation Guidelines   [Temperature Check] Guidelines for MKR compensation  Last week, Recognized Delegate @CodeKnight submitted a poll pointing out the disorganized nature of Core Unit MKR compensation, noting that current guidelines and methods vary significantly and are decoupled from the overall health of the DAO. Poll participants supported linking MKR compensation to the financial state of the DAO, rejected tying it to MKR’s price performance, and rejected standardizing it to implement equal compensation among Core Units. A few days later, CodeKnight submitted the proposal idea MIPX, which defines an annual amount of MKR each Core Unit will receive in compensation to bolster personnel recruitment and retention efforts. The proposed distribution method is to transfer MKR compensation to each Core Unit Facilitator, who will have the flexibility to work out the best way of distributing the funds for their unique Core Unit situation. The proposed compensation amount is 75% of Core Unit salaries with a four-year vesting schedule and a one-year cliff.  Governance Voting Incentive Campaign  Events Core Unit Facilitator @PonJerry posted a plan for incentivizing small MKR holders to participate in MakerDAO governance via a voting incentive campaign. The idea is to leverage the high demand for DAIvinity tickets by offering them as a reward for participating in governance voting. Potential benefits include:  An increase of <50 MKR holder participation Promotion for people to procure MKR and start participating in governance voting Increased social media chatter about MKR voting Drawing more social media attention to Maker generally Better representation of MKR holders at DAIvinity events    Special Purpose Fund Proposals  Special Purpose Fund for The Ambassador Program  This RFC from @kat outlines Subproposal MIP55c3-SP7, which asks for an allocation of 81,000 DAI to the Ambassador Program, an initiative that aims to create further MakerDAO resources and educational content in languages other than English. So far, the program has focused primarily on Spanish, resulting in a significant increase in Latin American users and topics on the forums—the top post of 2022 by SourceCred credits is in Spanish.   Legal Domain Work on Greenlit Collateral (bIBTA) Special Purpose Fund  This RFC from the Strategic Finance Core Unit’s @adcv requests a 50k DAI advance to cover legal expenses involved in the greenlit bIBTA application. The funding will investigate any potential legal consequences of onboarding a bIBTA Vault, a prerequisite to continuing technical work on the project.   The Chopping Block - Live Debate  The Chopping Block Live! - with Hasu & Rune - YouTube  @Hasu and @rune participated in a live debate with Compound’s Robert Leshner and others on the future of MakerDAO. Topics covered include:  MakerDAO’s business model, potential implications of the TornadoCash sanctions on MakerDAO’s collateral strategy, and Hasu and rune’s different approaches to DAO governance. 2582×565 112 KB  Hi everyone, thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Whether you hold MKR or DAI, own a vault, or want to get more involved in governance, this is your one-stop shop for MakerDAO updates. Authors: @alec, @nothsa, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon  Online PDF Version     CURRENT EVENTS  DAOs are often judged for their shortcomings, but as for their triumphs? Well, maybe success just doesn’t sell. Instead, the peanut gallery congregates en masse, armed with smug grins and cheap rhetoric. The past two weeks have been messy. There’s no denying that, but we’ve also seen a tremendous response from the greater community towards establishing a viable plan of action in the interim. And therein lies a DAO’s strength - built-in redundancy that enables swift responses to hindering problems.  MIP41c5-SP10: Facilitator Offboarding (RWF-001)  Authored by Recognized Delegates @ultraschuppi and @JustinCase, this MIP proposes the offboarding of RWF-001’s incumbent Facilitator. To summarize its motivations: ⮟  Per the proposal, @williamr is “actively divesting” RWF-001 from its duties. Further, current RWF-001 projects have been left “abandoned”, and its mandates to various CUs remain “unfulfilled”.  This MIP is meant to provide MKR holders an option for action if, by the time the proposal moves on-chain, RWF-001 continues to shirk the responsibilities outlined in its mandate. That said, a tangible plan of action, articulated and executed by williamr, is preferred. The MIPS and proposals below represent the work mandated to RWF-001, currently being advanced by separate Core Units and interested parties.  MIP55c3-SP8: Legal Work on MIP65 Special Purpose Fund  This MIP, penned by @adcv, @aes, and @SebVentures, requests an SPF totaling 30k DAI to reimburse @christiancdpetersen for the legal work required to advance the deal ratified in MIP65: Monetalis Clydesdale | Liquid Bond Strategy & Execution. Funding Breakdown ⮟  Posted within MIP65, williamr shares his updated thoughts on the state and continuance of the project.  I am recommending an amendment to MIP65 based on changes related to responsibility in the performance of the legal work for this structure. The MIP65 was originally drafted with a scope in mind which is currently changing as per funding requests by other core units: CES and SF. With that in mind, it is only natural that the accountability for verifying the performance of legal duties is also amended to reflect the changes in responsibility for undertaking the work. Or at a minimum, supervising that the legal review is done in accordance with best practices. Given that RWF is not engaging the legal contractor to perform the review on MIP65, it is natural it should not have the responsibility for supervising its proper execution. I am therefore requesting that governance aligns the accountability for verification of legal & governance structure with the responsibility of the performance of the task of legal review. Therefore placing the accountability with the responsible core unit, whichever team contracts the legal services for this MIP. Thanks, William   Collateral Onboarding Project-based Funding Request (PFR)  In response to the above, Monkey.irish requests a Project-based Funding Request (PFR) to use the existing CES-001 core unit budget for professional services related to the management and on-boarding of collateral assets. Funding Breakdown ⮟ The PFR requests approval for the use of:  44,000 DAI, or 45% of CES-001’s current Professional Services budget line item. 56,000 DAI, or 40% of CES-001’s current Contingency Buffer line item.  The proposal notes that this total, or 100k DAI, only represents an allocation due to the significant variance in the costs of professional services specific to real-world assets (RWAs). Under the terms of this proposal, CES-001 would fulfill the onboarding and management requirements of RWAs, a role currently mandated to the RWF-001. Note: this proposal is meant as an alternative to the various SPFs stemming from deals stalled by the current RWF-001 situation.    Huntingdon Valley Bank RWA Deal - Official Announcement!      Credit: @Growth-Core-Unit  Today is a defining moment to truly envision the potential of connecting decentralized finance and real-world finance. Huntingdon Valley Bank and Maker pioneer the first commercial loan participation between a U.S. Regulated Financial Institution and a decentralized digital currency. Maker is connecting to the legacy economy through the largest real-world asset vault to date and its first relationship with a US-based bank. This integration involves a 100 million DAI participation facility to support the growth of Huntingdon Valley Bank’s existing and new businesses.    Delegate Priority Surfacing Tool - Round 1 Results  Recognized Delegate @rspa shared the survey results he issued to delegates last month. The survey was intended to serve as a “consensus enabling tool” by revealing delegates’ biggest priorities for the next three months. Participants were asked first to enter priority topics in a spreadsheet, then to distribute 1,000 points between the priority topics already collected to help determine a “collective prioritization score.”  1035×358 39.4 KB  The top three priorities were:  Increasing vault usage (2399.84 points) Increasing DAI supply (1844 points) Ramping up MIP65 and other PSM yield strategies (1824 points)  The community received this initiative well, which strongly favors undertaking another round.   Llama’s delegation program as Delegation Captain  @luca_pro announced on Discord that he would join Recognized Delegate @Llama’s delegation program as Delegation Captain, heading up Llama’s public communications. Llama works with many well-known DAOs and DeFi protocols, including Aave, Uniswap, Gitcoin, and more. Check out their Delegate Platform here.   Frontier Research Delegate Platform  @Matt_NZ published his Delegate Platform as Frontier Research LLC. Matt, who has been actively following MakerDAO since 2019, is a New Zealand lawyer and legal scholar specializing in the intersection of law and technology. He specializes in decentralized finance, decentralized governance, and the regulatory environment around emerging technologies.   The Schuppi and ElPro Delegate Happy Hour Featuring Greg DiPrisco of RWA Co!  @g_dip of RWA Company LLC stopped by the latest episode of The Schuppi and ElPro Delegate Happy Hour to help our favorite hosts (and viewers) get a handle on Maker’s push into Real World Assets is going—and to talk a little bit about whisky. Watch the full episode here. 2587×575 114 KB  Hi everyone, thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Whether you hold MKR or DAI, own a vault, or want to get more involved in governance, this is your one-stop shop for MakerDAO updates. Authors: @alec, @nothsa, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon  Online PDF Version     CURRENT EVENTS  We live in an era defined by change. We witnessed the rise of technology and the emergence of the information age. We watched Web2’s slow decay from unadulterated creativity to a corporate sandbox. Furthermore, we saw the rise of financial cryptography, which, if you are here today, has likely struck a chord with you. All this to say, the world around us and our interpretation of it is moving at a rate never before experienced. Unfortunately, speed doesn’t always correlate with efficiency. Hard times come steeped with hard choices, even more so in business. Hierarchical models have centuries of data and frameworks to refer to; however, the rulebook for Web3 has not yet been written. All the same, community members took it upon themselves to get the ball rolling. Their first order of business: develop a standardized framework for CU offboarding.  MIP4c2-SP15: Core Unit Offboarding Process Amendments  Recognized Delegate @twblack88, in conjunction with @gfxlabs, @blimpa, and @Gala, authored and released an amended framework for Core Unit Offboarding, dubbed MIP4c2-SP15. The framework was polled and ratified on-chain on August 8th, with nearly 87% of voters in support. As we wade through numerous offboarding proposals, it would be beneficial to view them through the lens of this new framework. Summary of its motivations ⮟  The MIP’s original motivation was to clarify and simplify the CU offboarding process, with the overall goal of reducing dysfunction in the event of a business disruption. In addition to the alterations stemming from the proposed MIP, necessary changes to MIPs 38, 39, and 41 were also recommended to streamline the process further and limit the DAO’s exposure to painful, time-consuming tangents.  Summary of its goals ⮟  Solidify the Core Unit offboarding process.  Simplify and templatize the process for offboarding. Clarify offboarding terms within the governance cycle. Establish a standard for proposers.   Introduce and format expectations on project timelines, workflow, and budgetary processes. Have the offboarding process reference the new Core Unit Budget process (pending approval). Add templates where appropriate, or finalize WIP from the original MIP4. Propose an unwinding plan for core units with legacy budgets as the revised MIP40 came along.  Changes to MIPs 38, 39, and 41 - made in conjunction with the proposed MIP⮟   MIP38 - The new framework for CU offboarding was added, as well as the means to propose an offboarding through one MIP subcomponent.  MIP39 - References were added to the requisite MIPS, and the framework’s definition was finalized.  MIP41 - The offboarding process was mentioned, but not clearly defined. Further, no framework was in place to handle the loss of a CU Facilitator. Language was added to remedy both issues.  A detailed breakdown of the above changes can be found in the links provided above. With this framework in mind, let’s review the progression of the most recent offboarding proposals.  MIP39c3-SP2: Strategic Happiness Core Unit (SH-001) Offboarding  The original proposal was withdrawn in favor of a new MIP penned under the guidance and specifications of the above framework. Under the proposed terms, a severance of 45K DAI - or around 33% of its ratified annual salary -  will be awarded to the unit’s Facilitator per a passing vote. The MIP is set to enter its one-week Frozen Period on September 1st and will be included in the September governance cycle. This proposal can be discussed here or through the link above.  MIP41c5-SP10: Facilitator Offboarding (IS-001)  In the MIPs sub-proposal, blimpa of GovAlpha provides an updated timeline of events and links to relevant resources. A transcription can be found below.  This is a valid offboarding proposal under the currently approved governance process.  MIP40c3-SP77 (Budget Modification) along with MIP41c5-SP10 (Facilitator Offboarding) aims to offboard the Immunefi Security Core Unit (IS-001). If the offboarding proposal is ratified, the existing DAI and MKR vesting streams will be canceled. This proposal asks the Community or IS-001 to propose an adequate severance plan for the contributors. No execution plan is provided. This proposal has been assigned High-Impact based on the methodology listed here. This author of the proposal has stated that they are willing to keep the proposal in RFC after a compromise has been reached.  This proposal is set to enter its Frozen Period on September 1st and will be included in the September Governance Cycle.  MIP41c5-SP11: Facilitator Offboarding (SF-001)  Proposed on August 9th, this MIP requests the removal of @aes, SF-001’s incumbent Facilitator. Its motivations are sparse, but a summary can be found below. Summary of its motivations ⮟  SF became increasingly more expensive without showing much value. A blurry mandate became experiments that can be a waste of time and risky projects. "We’re Building Something, Here, Detective, We’re Building It From Scratch. All The Pieces Matter.” Det. Lester Freamon   The unit advocates for a “bear market strategy,” but its budget has seen significant increases over the year. The unit advocates for a “bear market strategy,” but its budget has seen significant increases over the year. However, this followed the new MIP40 guidelines, which passed to grant SF-001 their ‘business as usual’ budget, approved by MKR token holders. The proposal argues a lack of results given its budget, as well as a general “lack of professionalism” in its handling.  In line with the above, this MIP is set to enter its Freeze Period on September 1st and will be included in the September Governance Cycle. Discussion to this point has been limited, but a link to the parent thread can be found here, or via the above header link. Hi everyone, thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Whether you hold MKR or DAI, own a vault, or want to get more involved in governance, this is your one-stop shop for MakerDAO updates. Authors: @alec, @nothsa, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon  Online PDF Version     CURRENT EVENTS  Sometimes, the proper introduction has already been written. @g_dip provides a detailed account of Maker’s recent movement, activity, and drama in the Twitter thread below.   twitter.com    Greg Di Prisco | gdip.eth @g_dip  A thread summarizing the latest Maker Drama™   How we went from onboarding a US Commercial Bank to discussing how to depeg from the US dollar in less than two months.  (1/38) https://t.co/dtYs0tL3PP   8:46 PM - 30 Aug 2022           1K                240             MakerDAO Expenses Dashboard is live!  @Lenkla and the SES CU provide details on the soft-release of the MakerDAO Ecosystem Performance Dashboard, dubbed Maker Expenses. Summarized goals of the initial release: ⮟  Provide a clear overview of all the MakerDAO Core Units, their mandate, related MIPs, and practical info such as their social media profiles. Enable all Core Unit Administrators to easily submit their monthly budget reports in a standardized format, including Core Unit expenses and a rolling three-month forecast. Allow Core Units and their auditors to easily access and review monthly budget reports in a single location.  Per SES, the dashboard is built atop three core components: ⮟  1. The Dashboard UI   1920×1080 150 KB  As the primary focus of the initial release, the UI allows interested parties to review and verify all submitted budget reports in one central location.  2. The CU Budget Reporting Tool  This tool allows CUs to securely and conveniently upload their data through the provided API. Initially launched in June of this year, the focus will shift towards onboarding any remaining CUs.  3. The Ecosystem Performance API  This underlying component heavily bolsters data availability, enabling a means to permissionless access data relevant to the community, the greater Maker Ecosystem, and third-party builders. Next Steps: ⮟ In the immediate future, the focus will be centered on:  Onboarding the rest of the Core Units; Ensuring that the data is complete, correct, and up to date; Incremental UX and other improvements based on user feedback.   “Further down the road, we will target a broader user base, add more features, and advance the Dashboard as the primary collaboration tool for DAO stakeholders.”   The MIP-set currently known as MIPXX  A flurry of new MIPs was posted Wednesday, September 7th, each tagged as MIPXX. This MIP-set spans a range of topics, projects, and ideas linked to the Endgame Plan. The complete list is linked above, with a summary of their contents to follow. MIPXX: LDO to MKR OTC Swap Summarized Posted by @rune, this MIP is meant to be an optional inclusion in the finalized Endgame Launch Plan. If passed as proposed, changes to the protocol include:  Swap 20M LDO (Lido Governance Token) for MKR currently held in the Pause Proxy Transactions would be handled through Rune’s holding company, Calteram Holdings The swap would come at a “large discount” in the DAO’s favor  A link to the MIP’s listed motivations can be found here. MIPXX: Activate Protocol Owned Vault Emulation Summarized Also posted by Rune, this MIP activates the Protocol Owned Vault Emulation, dubbed POVE. If passed as proposed, the following changes would be enacted:  The Protocol Owned Vault Emulation (POVE) would be activated This approach aims to emulate the “outcome of operating a Protocol Owned Vault.” The initial collateral would include: any Lido-staked ETH, EtherDAI, DAI, or any LDO held in the Pause Proxy. The POVE would be bootstrapped with 40MM DAI to be used to acquire the initial Lido-staked ETH collateral  Proposed Parameters ⮟   MIPXXc5: An initial collateralization ration of 225%, resulting in 1.8x leverage on said collateral  MIPXXc6: This component enables a monthly Subproposal Process to modify the Collateralization Ratio:  MIPXXc7: Under this MIP any DAI (up to 500k DAI per day) available in Pause Proxy would be used to purchase Lido-staked ETH, and later EthDAI.  MIPXXc9: All additional income generated by the Maker Protocol would also be used to fund the Protocol Owned Vault unless DAI has reached 75% collateralization through “decentralized assets.”  MIPXXc10: “If the price of the collateral assets is above the POVEC virtual price ceilings, they are only counted as being equal to the virtual price ceilings when calculating the POVEDC.”  MIPXX: Monetalis/Coinbase Appaloosa Summarized Posted by @Allan_Pedersen, this MIP seeks to onboard a DAI 500MM real-world asset vault to be used to acquire and loan USDC through the PSM. These loans would be granted to Coinbase and split into six, nine, and 12-month terms. ETH or BTC would be provided as collateral. Summary of proposed structure ⮟ The payment flow would be handled as follows:  Interest paid monthly in USDC to Coinbase Account Immediately converted via PSM to DAI DAI Immediately paid into Surplus Buffer  The vault must provide:  Debt Ceiling of 500 million DAI. Stability Fee of 0% (surplus is paid manually through the legal structure, as specified in MIPXXc1) All other parameters must be set to ensure they have no functional impact.  MIPXX Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards Summarized Posted by @CB_Institutional, this MIP aims to onboard an “account representing MakerDAO” to Coinbase Prime and transfer 33% - or 1.6B - of the PSM’s USDC into custody to earn “rewards with Coinbase.” Summary of motivations ⮟  The proposal was made in response to MIP13c3-SP12: Invest in Short-term Bonds. Maker’s balance sheet is exposed mainly to USDC — in exchange for zero holding reward. Maker believes it is beneficial to safely be rewarded for holding collateral in USDC. This MIP outlines a clear path to providing up to 1.5% APY on USDC in the form of USDC Rewards and optimizing liquidity at zero cost to and industry-leading security for Maker.  MIPXX: Recognized Launch MetaDAO Clusters This MIP is also a part of the Endgame Plan Approval MIP set aiming to configure the “Clusters” for the launch of MetaDAOs.  “The Endgame Plan has been discussed in the Maker Community for more than six months and is now going up for a vote with the Endgame Plan Approval MIP Set. The Recognized Launch MetaDAO Clusters MIP is a required part of the Endgame Plan Approval MIP Set. It sets up the MetaDAO Clusters to begin work immediately on preparing for the Endgame Plan Launch.”  Summary of terms and proposal ⮟  A MetaDAO Cluster is a formally recognized MetaDAO led by a Facilitator that’s mandated to prepare an onboarding proposal. The currently envisioned overview tracks as follows:    ETH WARSZAWA: The Schuppi & El Pro MakerDAO Delegate Happy Hour at ETHWarsaw 2022  Summarized Table of Contents ⮟  The Visionary of Eth Warsaw: Paweł of @Oracles-Core-Unit Juan of the @SES-Core-Unit “The Dashboard” Project Based Financing Proposal via Juan Retro’s thoughts on the possible inefficiencies that the Endgame might encounter Chris from L2 Beat Chris’ thoughts on the MakerDAO Teleport Sam McPerson of PECU presenting at ETHWarsaw 2022 Official Announcement of the Oracles-Core-Unit’s product, The Chronicle by Nik   Video Guide to Delegating MKR  Recognized Delegate @CodeKnight provides a video guide detailing how to delegate MKR tokens. This guide is helpful to newcomers and Maker vets looking to participate in on-chain governance actively. A link to the original post and the GitHub repo to embed the video can be found below.   Forum Post | Github repo    Some thoughts about the resilience of decentralized stablecoins  In a recent blog post, JP Koning provides a well-versed and sometimes dissenting opinion on the importance of “seizable assets” with the uncertain cloud of regulation looming. The post came as a retort to a recent forum thread, Endgame Plan timeline to free-floating Dai, specifically addressing the proposed “Phoneix Stance.”  1124×619 338 KB  Per the post:  “While in phoenix stance, Maker would no longer rely on RWA. By RWA, [Rune] refers to centralized stablecoins such as USD Coin and loans to banks and other financial institutions with a physical address and a regulator. These are the sorts of assets that can be used by authorities as a lever to hurt the Maker protocol. With nothing for authorities to confiscate, presumably, Maker would be resilient to attempts by authorities to shut it down.”  Koning disagrees with this stance, as the seizing of assets is just one of many levers that authorities could use to halt a protocol. Take, for instance, Tornado Cash. Rather than asset seizure, sanctions were instead levied against the software. Koning argues that sanctions levied against Maker would garner similar results:  A decrease in licit DAI usage, removal of collateral from the protocol, delisting of DAI on significant exchanges and fiat off-ramps, and finally; a drying up of liquidity.  Koning believes focusing on seizure resistance (i.e., Phoenix Stance) will not render “Maker meaningfully more resilient” - however, the removal of real-world assets will. This concept is presented as a double-edged sword of sorts. The removal of RWAs makes the system less usable, as, without centralized reserves, the peg is more likely to see a strong variance. Conversely, introducing RWAs makes the DAO more practical and attracts many additional users. Koning argues that makes the DAO more likely to fall under regulatory scrutiny. The post ends with an attempt at framing a solution:  "Stakeholders should ask themselves how relevant Maker has become. Has Maker become so important (and its public perception so negative) that it is about to attract the baleful eyes of regulators? If so, one defensive option is to engage in a rational form of self-sabotage: make the tool less useful. This will shrink the pool of Maker users, thus the tool’s visibility to regulators and, therefore, the likelihood of it being shut down. Real-world assets enter into the picture because their removal is one way to impinge on the system’s usefulness. Of course, if a protocol starts engaging in self-sabotage, then the people making this decision better be sure that their original assumption – that regulators are furious – is correct."  A link to the full post can be found here or through the above link.    This Week in Governance   Weekly MIPs Update #103  Ratification polls, proposals, and pre-MIP discussions. image2585×572 111 KB  Hi everyone, thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Whether you hold MKR or DAI, own a vault, or want to get more involved in governance, this is your one-stop shop for MakerDAO updates. Authors: @alec, @nothsa, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon  Online PDF Version     CURRENT EVENTS   The Merge   On September 15 at 06:42:42 UTC at block 15537393, the Ethereum mainnet merged with Ethereum’s Beacon Chain at the Terminal Total Difficulty of 58750000000000000000000. Ethereum’s complete transition from a Proof-of-Work consensus algorithm into a Proof-of-Stake consensus has been successfully completed.     beaconcha.in    Open Source Ethereum Blockchain Explorer - Index - beaconcha.in - 2022 beaconcha.in makes the Ethereum 2.0. beacon chain accessible to non-technical end users      The expectation of the merge was an odd thing. Given enough time, misconceptions and inaccuracies obfuscate the tangible reality of an event, and mythos is born. The Merge has finally happened, but as we approached the “Difficulty Bomb,” many still do not quite understand the nuances of this transition. Fortunately, we can attempt to sift through the noise and separate fact from myth. To that end, several CUs have been hard at work priming a detailed plan of action come Merge-day.  Risk-001 Summary: Merge Risks and Market Impacts  Presented by @monet-supply, this thread details the many intricacies of the merge with a primary focus on its market impacts. Recently, we have seen an increased focus on the potential PoW Ethereum forks. Chain forks are not new (see Ethereum Classic or Bitcoin Cash), but the prevalence of centralized stablecoins, DeFi, and cross-chain bridges have made forking a much greater challenge than it once was. Potential market risks include:    Futures backwardation and negative funding Impact:  Nominal cost of leverage through futures contracts (excluding potential fork value) declines, creating competitive pressure vs. Maker vaults Users who consider market implied fork value to be too high are incentivized to leverage on futures, while those considering implied value too low may prefer leveraging with Maker vaults (where the vault owner will still receive any potential fork tokens)  Responses:  Maintain competitive rates to avoid losing too much volume to futures contracts    stETH Discount Impact:  Possible increase in stETH liquidity risk and downside volatility stETH discount could incentivize leveraged staking behavior, which would increase the risk of negative price gaps while raising ETH supply rates on lending protocols  Responses:  Monitor stETH liquidity and respond with parameter changes (increasing stability fee or liquidation ratio) if necessary Monitor competitive rates using ETH collateral across DeFi lending protocols    External Asset Fork Choice Impact:  Minimal impact for Maker if all externally backed asset issuers support merge upgrade If one or more issuer supports POW fork, this could cause a significant impact on DEX liquidity pools and other protocols accepting the asset as collateral  Responses:  Confirm merge support from key external asset providers that interact with Maker protocol, including Circle, Paxos, Binance, Bitgo, Gemini, Centrifuge issuers, other RWA issuers, and services bridging DAI out to other chains. (eg. Wormhole, Axelar, Gravity Bridge, Multichain) Minimal impact if all externally backed asset issuers support merge upgrade If one or more issuer supports POW fork, this could cause a significant impact on DEX liquidity pools and other protocols accepting the asset as collateral    Liquidity Pool Protocols Impact:  Possible migration of some users from external lending protocols to Maker vaults Possible withdrawals of ETH from lending protocols putting pressure on stETH Near the merge, the potential for a decline in decentralized exchange liquidity for ETH pairings  Responses:  Monitor user behavior and maintain competitive rates to facilitate any potential migrations or user acquisition Monitor stETH leverage positions and ETH lending utilization on Aave, Euler Monitor exchange liquidity and consider parameter changes if needed    Oracle Networks and Indices Impact:  Increased possibility of bad / outlier data delivered to oracle feeds Possibility of market disruption due to bad price data incorporated in third-party oracles or perp indices  Responses:  Confirm centralized exchange plans concerning POW fork listing, tickers, and API changes Encourage industry players to adopt alternative ticker for any POW fork, avoid collisions, and ensure continuity of mainnet Ethereum data    Replay Attacks Impact:  Increased possibility of unintended transactions on mainnet, replayed from POW fork chain (e.g., closing vault positions, selling fork-DAI or fork-MKR tokens, etc.) Possibility of mainnet transactions, including Maker oracle and keeper operations, being replayed to POW fork chain  Responses:  Share info about replay attack risk within the Maker community Advocate for POW fork to use alternative chain-id (instead of chain-id 1, which will continue to be used by mainnet Ethereum) to avoid replaying transactions    PECU Announcement: Maker Protocol, the Merge and Future Forks of Ethereum  Replay attacks are not specific to DAI or MKR tokens - raw ether, ERC20 tokens, ERC721 NFTs, and all other digital assets can be transferred through replay attacks. Any transaction broadcast to the PoW network can be replayed on the PoS network if they share the same chainId. Some examples of interactions that may be replayable:  Interacting with any Maker contracts on PoW directly (from the same address you used before the fork) Selling PoW DAI or MKR tokens to someone in a peer-to-peer transaction Interacting with PoW DAI or MKR tokens via a dApp (such as selling them on UniSwap)  In summary: anything you do on PoW ETH may be able to be replayed on PoS ETH, and you should assume that it can be replayed on PoS.
