The current CSI stakeholders decide to wait until after the merge and for new updates on the rETH protocol to be live to reassess whether to continue the onboarding efforts.  Oracles Update: post-merge   2291×312 31.4 KB     In Other News…  MakerDAO’s Window of Opportunity  The recent article posted by rekt.news posits that, from the outside looking in, Maker’s path forward is becoming increasingly unclear. Before the window of opportunity closes entirely, the DAO must first face an “internal struggle”:  Preserve the ideals of cryptography, and reject the legacy system entirely, Or embrace growth regardless of the route taken.  Since the collapse of UST, stablecoin issuers have had a singular focus: long-term stability. In the wake of the collapse, fiat-backed stables offered a “safe haven” from the extreme volatility. And then came the Tornado Cash sanctions and the freezing of all associated USDC, adding fuel to an already raging fire.  “The OFAC sanctions have been a harsh wake-up call for DeFi, bringing into focus the vulnerabilities associated with forfeiting autonomy in place of growth.”  Per the article, a diverse range of options and motivations were presented: For instance, Why Maker has no choice but to prepare to free float Dai, comes in stark contrast to MIP81: Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards. These proposals are the “dividing line” between the two conflicting ethea. To free float, DAI would fully embrace crypto’s root ideals and move forward with the Coinbase proposal emphasizing growth over the route taken. All this to say, this “struggle” is inevitable. Not just for MakerDAO, but all DeFi protocols wading through this undefined era. Despite the accusatory tone the publication has come to be known for, the piece ends with an air of respect.  "Although controversial, Rune’s proposed gameplan may also usher in a new paradigm of non-reliance on the dollar, potentially putting DeFi out of the reach of those who want to see it stamped out. In proposing such bold steps, Rune is risking the death of DAI, this time by his hand. Nevertheless, faced with increasing volatility in the “real” world, with fiat currencies rapidly devaluing and no near-term end, the window of opportunity is closing fast. …Crypto’s original cypherpunk ethos may be a lifeline as we spiral into an ever more volatile future."  Extended drawbacks have a way of making us doubt the things we once held as givens. So, as we traverse our path unknown, ask ourselves who we are and who we can be. Because once again, MakerDAO’s writing the script for present and future protocols to follow. 2572×575 110 KB  Hi everyone, thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Whether you hold MKR or DAI, own a vault, or want to get more involved in governance, this is your one-stop shop for MakerDAO updates. Authors: @alec, @nothsa, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon  Online PDF Version     CURRENT EVENTS   Endgame RFC DVC Calls  Recognized Delegate @twblack88 has hosted an open call to discuss and workshop the Endgame MIP-set. Summary of the discussion’s goals and format As they stand, DVC (Decentralized Voter Committee) calls need more structure. These calls aim to surface particular topics and coordinate themes to focus the discussion on certain areas of the vast array of proposals. Endgame RFC Calls are held without the author of the discussed MIP to better shape feedback and to identify unbiased questions and concerns. This feedback gets honed into actionable items that focus DVC discussion on particular areas of interest or concern. Last week, the initial results of these meetings were shared in the appropriate thread, summarized below. RFC-DFV Feedback to Endgame Plan v3 Complete Overview High-level direct endgame challenges:  Why not a phased rollout? What exactly is the point of bundling MIPs together? Many moving parts need a detailed execution plan to get right. There is so much research and work/iterations in this design, but what’s missing is the implementation plan. What’s with the extended mandates around RWA? Shouldn’t there be incentives for collaboration and cooperation? MetaDAOs must be dynamic with exemplary leadership, a credible plan, and understandable tokenomics. Lacking those fundamentals is setting them up for failure. How do we ensure everyone interprets the information and context of the plan as intended? How can we iterate to make this better? How can we ensure that launching metaDAOs is not reinventing the governance wheel repeatedly?  RFC-DFV Feedback to MIP83: Launch MetaDAO Clusters  Is the clustering organic, or do we want to put some structure into creating the metaDAOs? Do current teams pick a color? The definition of these mDAO types is missing from the MIP. It probably needs another component explaining the protector, creator, and governor DAOs. Things like what roles are initially present, expected responsibilities, interaction (or not) with other metaDAOs, constraints on business, the definition of intangible value, etc. Highly recommend a legal audit. What levels of governance will be owned by the MetaDAOs versus Maker core? If we are still using the executive vote mechanism to pass MIPs… how do the governance systems interact? How do the budget and incentives work when metaDAOs form? How do budgets change as the metaDAOs bootstrap? What does this look like when they are fully operational? What is the relationship between scopes and clusters?  RFC-DFV Feedback to MIP84: Activate Protocol-Owned Vault Emulation  Surplus buffer changes wildly if we have excess liabilities. dss-kiln was never tested or audited. Is there a way to slowly scale this up test by test? (1 mil at a clip was suggested) Where is the leverage coming from? Seems like this is out of sequence? Wouldn’t the POVE be after ETHD?  RFC-DFV Feedback to MIP39c3-SP4: Offboarding the Events Core Unit (EVENTS-001)  Does the EVENTS-001 Failed Offboarding carry any weight? Governance just said ‘no’ to offboarding events; what’s the point if it’s up for a vote again? Should offboarding, in general, be bundled?  RFC-DFV Feedback to MIP39c3-SP3: Offboarding the Strategic Happiness Core Unit (SH-001)  Are the offboarding(s) necessary to Endgame? How does Marketing play into Endgame?  These calls represent an ideal starting point if you want to understand the Endgame Plan or participate in its development. Endgame DVC RFC calls are held on Friday at 14:30 UTC. Meeting details can be found via this link, or through the original post.  Endgame: Informal Sentiment Poll  Posted by @psychonaut, the poll aims to gauge community sentiment surrounding the Endgame Plan, with all votes remaining anonymous.  691×314 14 KB  ‘No’ currently leads with around 38% of the total votes.  Endgame Breakdown with LongForWisdom on the ‘The Raphael, Schuppi, & ElPro MakerDAO Happy Hour’  @LongForWisdom shared detailed, unbiased insight into the current Endgame design and followed with a post outlining his interpretations of the model’s strengths and weaknesses. All of these will be covered in summary below.  Summary of the discussion:  MetaDAOs fuse the creation of a new DAO with an individual Core Unit or Units. Under this format, contributors form a new DAO aligned with Maker and its principles. This alignment must be placed before goals separate from the DAO. The structure allows for more governance direction but “a way that benefits both Maker and the metaDAO itself.”  "The idea is, as you participate in Maker Core as a contributor or customer, you accrue these [meta]Tokens and become involved with the [growth and activities] of the metaDAO. “Maker benefits by creating a redundant, decentralized workforce.”  MetaDAOs are incentivized to perform to the full extent of their mandate and are held fully responsible for their actions relative to the Maker Protocol. This scenario benefits the theoretical metaDAO while shielding Maker from major disruptions affecting the central product. They do not, however, come without risk.  “The first risk I want to highlight is the risk that MetaDAOs cannot create/attract/retain meaningful communities.”  1. Not everyone wants to create and manage an entire community.  “I hypothesize that, in general, the ability and desire to attract, create, organize and operate a community is rarer than most assume. Further, individuals with both the desire and ability are likely to self-select themselves into roles where they can express that ability and desire naturally.”  2. Self-determination seems to have been a key rallying point in existing DAO Communities, and MetaDAOs cannot meaningfully self-determine.  “Without the commitment to decentralization from the Maker Foundation, I doubt as many individuals would have been attracted to the project. Anecdotally, I would not have been.”  3. The given examples of successful Meta-Engineering don’t have very successful or high-quality communities. Examples of these endeavors came through Uniswap, Unit Bias Memecoin, and the early BTC community. Further, he questions the utility and inherent value of these proposes mDAO tokens.  “This might be more tidily summed up by the question: “Would you be willing to get paid for your work only in vested MDAO tokens?” I’d argue that a large share of individuals wouldn’t work solely for vested MKR tokens, let alone MDAO tokens.”  Lastly, the issue of politics, and its interlaced drama, was addressed - a source of distraction that Long believes metaDAOs may amplify rather than contain. In a flat organization like a DAO, the humanity of business is a very noticeable factor. Altering the structure of this relationship won’t mitigate the inevitability of human nature. But, separating the workforce won’t make it any less human. The same political issues will persist and could even be amplified by the inherent “ownership” attached to the establishment of a metaDAO.  The Protocol-owned vault (POVE)  As a very high-level overview, the POVE functions to acquire ETH and mint DAI. Traditionally, user-operated vaults are subjected to safety measures like stability fees, collateralization ratios, and liquidations to bolster Protocol security. Instead, The POVE is afforded certain luxuries to ensure it traverses a less adversarial path. As it’s owned and operated by Maker and not an end-user, it wouldn’t face the same set-in-stone stability fees and liquidation ratios. In a “trustless” space, these hard-coded “laws” are designed to shield the protocol from the intentions of unknown parties, but the POVE is owned and operated exclusively by the Maker Protocol.  “Because Maker owns this vault and is the only one using it, we don’t need as many explicit mechanisms to ensure its safety… We can, essentially, allow a lot more than we would for [user-owned] vaults.”  LFW sees many benefits to the proposed model, but peg security stands out as the most impactful for a few reasons.  This extra DAI can then be used to manage the peg through volatile stretches. Provided the POVE is fitted with ample ETH, Maker could mint and market sell DAI when its price is high and repurchase it if it drops below one dollar. In other words, arbitrage at scale. Something quite evident on the surface, but much collateral is needed to mint enough DAI to affect its market price in either direction. For example, to mint $3B DAI, the DAO would need to own $4B in ETH. The POVE then serves to slowly build ETH reserves, which could then be deployed to protect the peg if required.  RWAs Cash-like RWAs - These include options similar to the PSM or the procurement of US Treasury bonds. These assets aren’t fully decentralized but offer the DAO a means to earn consistent yield or expand DAI’s market reach. USDC is the most accurate example of this asset type currently being used. The primary benefit of this asset class is it affords DAI liquidity. This would allow the protocol to offer direct swaps through the PSM, meaning if the demand for DAI rapidly changes, this mechanism could absorb the market pressure. Clean Money RWAs - Long sees these assets as a net positive. If RWAs are to be a long-term part of the system, it would be ideal for the majority to be carbon negative or neutral. This initiative also serves to assuage potential regulation. If the protocol had a positive global impact, it would be far less politically feasible to “shut it down.” The call ended with a direct question. “Where do you see the most pressing risks in the current plan?” Long’s response was simple yet elegant.  “The major risk is that [Endgame’s] based on the assumption that may not turn out to be true.”    MakerDAO’s Past, Present, and Future with Rune Christensen Since we’re on the topic, we recommend to listen to this podcast episode of I Pledge Allegiance, which presents Rune Christensen who discusses MakerDAO’s origins, his exit from MakerDAO, and his recent return. Rune also elaborates on his Endgame plan for MakerDAO, which he hopes will lead the DAO forward a long time to come. Check out the episode here!   MKR and DAI comp discussions  Compensation discussion from Delegate office hours: This discussion is often approached, circled, and inevitably bookmarked, only to be picked up again, so the process repeats. This is due to the problem’s complexity and the variety of different approaches offered to date. It’s not just a matter of doing or not, but also where, how, and why. These conflicting factors make it difficult to standardize across the entire DAO. A flat rate across all units neglects achievements, prowess, and general importance to business continuity. And then on the other hand, the weighting of “importance” is subjective, differing from person to person. In other words, the problem itself is rooted in instability, so calculating the “correct” parameters is quite difficult. As @Aes put it:  “With something like this, the devil’s in the details.”  The call concludes by identifying areas with the least clarity, as those should take priority as we move toward a finely tuned framework. Compensation Discussion from Governance & Risk (timestamped) The proposal, authored by Recognized Delegate @CodeKnight, seeks to establish a standardized framework for contributor compensation. He spoke about the proposed changes during the last G&R call (linked above). First, this proposal was written as a means to grant the conversation legs. Assistance from anyone with more experience in vesting structures would be appreciated, as little feedback has been offered. Without a framework, we leave room for personal agendas to conflict with business. These lengthy vesting discussions not only cut into a CUs time but also often lead to conflict. CodeKnight hopes that, through a structured framework, contributors would have more insight into whether or not vesting is worth pursuing in a given period. This would ideally mean fewer proposals for delegates to dissect and less uncertainty for DAO contributors. @monkey.irish also spoke on the importance of talent retention. We’ve seen a recent trend of “tightening the belt buckle,” but he believes a certain misrepresentation exists. Many DAO contributors are not being overpaid relative to comparable positions in the traditional space, but quite the opposite. He worries that the DAO’s long-term strategic positioning could take a large hit if this trend continues.   Coinbase proposal discussion  GovAlpha Core Unit Facilitator Patrick_J presented some governance-related concerns regarding MIP81: Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards during last week’s Governance & Risk call. Among other issues, GovAlpha believes that MIP81:  Does not follow the standard MIP Template Is lacking in completeness and clarity, two of the five core principles outlined in MIP0  Is too focused on low-level information and lacking in high-level information Appears to instruct GovAlpha to oversee the transfer of funds to Coinbase without oversight from the wider MakerDAO organization  Proposed solutions include ensuring that the MIP adheres to the MIP template, appointing an Arranger, and adding provisions for assessment by a legal team and other Core Units. Check out the slides on this topic for a quick at-a-glance summary of GovAlpha’s viewpoint, or watch the video segment (about half an hour) if you’re interested in catching the full discussion.  Coinbase Live Call with CFO!   The discussion prompted GovAlpha to arrange a one-on-one public call with Coinbase’s Chief Financial Officer, Alesia Haas. The DAO would then be eligible to earn USDC rewards via the exchange. These rewards are estimated to provide up to 1.5% APY, netting the protocol a theoretical 24 million in annual revenue. Due to the nature of the proposed partnership, community sentiment appears to be split. In response, Coinbase CFO, Alesia Haas, joined GovAlpha for a live Q&A regarding the polarizing proposal. The call was allotted a 30-minute time slot, and only pre-screened questions were answered. It’s worth noting that while this may not be the meeting we’ve come to expect in Web3, the format is common practice in traditional business. Myriad community members posed several excellent questions, but due to time constraints, only a handful was addressed in detail. A full transcription of the call, provided by @Artem_Gordon, can be found here.  @TRUEMAKER breaks it down into digestible bytes.  A summary will be provided below, but the post can be read in its entirety via this link.  701×476 44.9 KB   Endgame Plan: Diagram of the Scopes and ecosystem  In this edition of the Endgame breakdown, @rune provides additional information about the scope and scale of the re-envisioned Maker ecosystem. The Endgame Plan identifies three broad categories of actors:   The Scopes remain closest to the “Maker Core.”  MetaDAOs function as semi-independent DAOs  Ecosystem Actors are entirely independent companies, individuals, or DAOs that provide service to Maker Core or its MetaDAOs.  What’s a Scope, and what does it do? Scopes detail and standardize how the various actors communicate and collaborate. They primarily function to maintain the “immutability” that is critical to the success of the Endgame plan and “Maker’s long-term survival.”  "The 11 Scopes are split into Primary Scopes and Supporting Scopes. The Primary Scopes are the activities that help grow and sustain Maker. They include Protocol Engineering, Decentralized Collateral, RWA Collateral, and Growth."  These scopes are covered in depth by three groups:  Decentralized Voter Committee Governor Councils Tribunals  Primary Scopes are large entities with a litany of available resources. As a marked “separation of powers,” these actors remain separate from the “Councils” that define the Scope Framework. These Councils are composed of representatives from all Governer MetaDAOs. Summarized Workflow Step 1: DVCs, Delegates, and Council agree on a Scope Framework. As an example, this could specify the process used to determine when it is worth it to deploy a new Synthetic Asset, such as EuroDai, and the steps that need to be followed when deploying a Synthetic Asset in accordance with best practice. Step 2: With the Scope Framework in place, the Core Units now have clear guidance on when and how to initiate the deployment of a new Synthetic Asset and how to determine which contributor (MetaDAO or Ecosystem Actor) that should be paid to carry out the work. Step 3: The last step is to construct the Executive vote that activates the new Synthetic Asset and wait for the MKR holders and Delegates to vote it through  "Fully specified processes like this example onboarding of a Synthetic Asset must be developed for each process in all 11 Scopes. Having the processes specified in the greatest detail possible prevents the risk of a grey area uncertainty becoming a beachhead for complexity expansion and scope creep." With so much to discuss, and so much being discussed, it’s exceptionally easy to get swept away. So, let’s take a moment to wade through the myriad of impactful proposals, dissect what they offer, and explore the current community sentiment.   Gemini: GUSD Proposal  Following in the wake of Coinbase’s proposed MIP81, two similar proposals hit the Forum last week. The first came via @tylerwinklevoss of Gemini, a top CEX and the issuer of the GUSD stablecoin. Per the announcement, Gemini has been a long-standing supporter of the Maker Protocol. For reference:  Custody: MKR has been supported on Gemini since August 2020 and Dai since April 2020. Trading: MKR trading was supported in September 2020 and Dai in May 2020. Earn: MKR is supported in the Gemini Earn product with 1.26% APY, and Dai with one of the highest rates at 5.31% APY to our users. Nifty Gateway: Nifty Gateway users can use their Gemini exchange account balances to purchase on NG. This means a Gemini exchange user who has Dai in their wallet can use it to pay on Nifty Gateway, where a conversion from ETH or USD takes place. Credit Card: Customers can select Dai and MKR as their rewards to earn instant crypto rewards on the Gemini Credit Card.  Summary of the proposal Per Gemini, a three-month program began on October 1, 2022, wherein Gemini contributes a fixed rate of 1.25% to the DAO on any GUSD present in the PSM. These rewards are to be paid out monthly provided a minimum average balance of 100M GUSD is maintained. Further, a legal entity would need to be set up and processed through KYC to claim these accrued rewards. As this was announced as a marketing incentive, GUSD held in the PSM will not be moved from the PSM or into Gemini custody.  “We recognize the importance of the PSM in securing Dai redemptions, and we believe keeping it on-chain is the best way to fulfill that task.”  The Gemini team also provided the following Dune query to aid in tracking the DAO’s GUSD holdings.   A link to the full announcement can be found here, or via the above link.   MIP87: OUSD Decentralized Rewards  The second was posted by @pete, representing the Origin Protocol, the issuer of the OUSD stablecoin. OUSD is a “yield-generating stablecoin that rebases positively and daily to distribute yield directly to user wallets.” Per the proposal, OUSD is backed 1:1 by DAI, USDC, and USDT. It generates its yield via lending to protocols such as Aave, Compound, Curve, and Convex. All accrued interest is then converted into OUSD and proportionally distributed. Summary of MIP87  The MIP suggests a 1% allocation that can be increased at any time as confidence grows. Maker would convert up to 33% of its USDC holdings to OUSD.   “Maker will store the OUSD in a rebase-capable wallet, such as MetaMask, Ledger, Coinbase Wallet, MEW, etc. If using a multi-sig wallet, Maker will “opt-in” to participate in the rebasing by calling OUSD’s rebaseOptIn() function. This can easily be enabled via the OUSD application in Gnosis Safe.”  “The Elephant in the Room”  “In November 2020, OUSD was exploited for $7M in funds. The DApp at the time included a clear disclaimer warning that the product was in BETA and that the contracts had not been audited. Nonetheless, the Origin treasury opted to cover the losses for these early OUSD holders… OUSD has not suffered another security failure since relaunching in January 2021.”  OUSD’s view on the Coinbase, Coinshares, and Gemini proposals  “Origin is aware of the proposals from Coinbase (MIP81), CoinShares (MIP86), and Gemini (Proposal: GUSD PSM). While these proposals are legitimate, we believe that it is in the best interest of Maker DAO and the Maker DAO community to remain as decentralized as possible with business partners moving forward and with the MIP13c3-SP12 investment, as neither Coinbase, CoinShares, nor Gemini align with Maker’s decentralized principles.”  The full proposal is linked above or can be viewed here. Summary of the proposal The perceived problem:  "Maker’s superpower has always been the cheap cost of capital due to the success of DAI as the most popular decentralized stablecoin. However, Maker has struggled to gain traction on the supply side. Our primary lending use case during the last bull run was as a wholesale lender to CEXes who would pocket the interest spread. This demonstrates the strong demand for frictionless, fast, low-fee user experiences. The only ones providing this at the moment are centralized exchanges. Maker can provide credit to these protocols / CEXes, but their missions may not align with the DAO. Maker is dependant on external counter-parties."  The proposed solution: The team aims to bring new life to Maker products by offering best-in-market rates due to low-cost capital infusions via D3M injections. Their initial product would be a fork of an existing best-in-class lending platform, retrofitted to integrate directly with Maker through the D3M.  “We will focus on large-scale market segments. We are not interested in supporting long tail assets - only ETH, BTC, and staked ETH derivatives.”  The platform would utilize two external oracles, Maker and Chainlink, to address the issues in security witnessed throughout DeFi. The proposal notes that the team is investigating the addition of a third oracle provider for future implementation. Q3 2022 MKR Decentralization, Delegation, and Distribution Update  @lyt of the Strategic Finance CU provides a high-level summary of selected metrics on the decentralization, delegation, and distribution of MKR governance. An Overview  Full Breakdown Summarized Most of these metrics saw a quarterly decrease outside of an increase in total holders. Further, some expired delegate contracts still hold an MKR balance. This can be viewed as a measure of the total amount of MKR represented by “passive delegators,” shown below.   Another notable trend correlates positively with delegation’s growth and distribution. While direct participation has been steadily declining, participation via delegation has thrived. Not just for top delegates but across the board.   The number of MKR holders with at least one token has been steadily increasing since May 2022. With that rise, we have seen a steady uptrend in the number of top wallets and entities required to compromise 50% of the available MKR holdings. This represents an increase in the MKR token’s overall decentralization. Per the report, this form of attack would take 23 of the top MKR wallets, suitable for a 17% YoY increase in protocol security. The post concluded with a look into MKR’s Gini coefficient, commonly used to measure income distribution. Its scale ranges from complete equality at 0 to complete inequality at 100. Maker previously used this metric to measure the concentration risk of accepted assets. High risk occurs when most of the debt comes from a few large vaults. This view, instead, utilizes the metric to assess MKR ownership.   MKR currently stands at a 96.69 Gini coefficient, representing a high degree of ownership inequality. That said, this figure stood at 96.74 on July 14th, showing slight signs of regression. Summarized Conclusions  There is a long-term governance trend of direct participation shifting to participation via delegation. There is a fair amount of MKR in expired delegated contracts for the first time. The number of participants of 1MKR+ represented in governance contract has been steadily increasing but trended slightly downward QoQ. We have seen slight increases in MKR decentralization since last quarter.  The full post can be found here or via the above link. To view the attached Dune Analytics Dash, click here. We might have been comfortable moving towards highest quality Corporate Bonds (AAA), but our concern about general market volatility (below) leads us to, unfortunately, propose leaving this asset class for the time being.”   General Market Volatility   " Whilst we might be comfortable about the long-term return and value of highly rated (AAA) corporate Bonds and long-term Government Bonds, we are concerned about short-term shocks in market values that could lead to sentiment-driven negative extreme shock actions on Maker and DAI. Viridian Cluster Introduction  The second Cluster application has arrived, and with it comes a naming convention. @Allan_Pedersen introduces the Viridian Cluster | Protector MetaDAO and breaks down the responsibilities of a Protector. To Summarize:  The Protector MetaDAO must deliver an RWA portfolio to Maker that can support a 1:1 USD peg. Maker benchmarks the Protector MetaDAO against US Treasury for 3-months, meaning the Protector must deliver alpha/spread against this benchmark. The Protector MetaDAO, as its core revenue from Maker, receives 10% of yield income up to the benchmark - and 25% of all yield above the benchmark. This revenue, and other income sources (such as frontend revenue share fees that are available to all MetaDAOs), go directly to the Protector MetaDAO Surplus Buffer (“PMSB”). The Protector MetaDAO can accrue value to Protector MetaDAO token holders by using funds in the PMSB to acquire Elixir (DAI/ETH/MKR liquidity provider tokens). The accumulated Elixir tokens are used to slowly buy and burn Protector MetaDAO tokens.  Guiding Principals The team intends to focus its attention on two key areas:  Arresting Climate Change Connecting Defi, CeFi, and TradFi in a net positive way  The team intends to address these issues using, what it calls, the Max Yield Equation, the flow of which can be seen in the below visual.  Viridian’s plans to tackle climate change:  Set a clear, simple, and strong standard for Climate Change investing that makes sense for the Protector MetaDAO community - and engage with relevant institutions/NGOs, etc, on evolving the standard. Focus investing in credit portfolio build-ups and seeding/encouraging asset strategies that meet this Community-based Climate Change standard - and resell as they meet an institutional threshold. Open up the above investment strategies of credit portfolio build-up and seeding investment strategies for like-minded third parties to participate in growing the base of investors participating in accelerating these important assets.   "The world’s asset holders remain starved for true, impactful, Climate Change assets. Using the (limited) heft of a Protector MetaDAO’s initial mandate of Maker to establish a machine to manufacture these assets will deliver substantial franchise value from premium on assets to the application of this machinery broadly to global investors."  Viridian’s plans to integrate DeFi/CeFi/TradFi:  Engagement with the regulators on finding a true north that is based upon gainful and safe integration between DeFi/CeFi/TradFi. More on this in our Regulatory/Legal section. Developing legal structures that can be governed by smart contracts, working appropriately with self-custody environments, and developing smart-contract integration with regulated asset custodians and regulated digital asset markets. Create Cash flow growth in “good” patterns of integration by “ensuring the capital controlled by the Protector MetaDAO flows through these models - and allow third parties to use our “high-speed high-way” for moving between TradFi/CeFi/DeFi (maybe with a little toll-booth on it…)”   "Paving a performing high-way that integrates digitally from DeFi to TradFI will have substantive value - the toll-booths the Protector MetaDAO can install on the high-way have the potential to generate massive cash flow as these markets integrate. There will not be many of these high-ways and first-movers working collaboratively across will, likely, have sticky advantages in terms of trust and size that is not easily supplanted."  A link to the full Proposal can be found here.   An EIP 4337 Rundown  Note: While the EIP is not Maker-centric, with the emergence of MetaDAOs, some of its proposed features could be beneficial in bolstering user adoption. EIP 4337 was originally introduced in September of last year but only recently gained traction. To summarize the issue addressed: Currently, EOA (Ledger, Trezor, etc.) and smart contract wallets (Metmask, MEW, etc.) operate under very different rulesets. Only EOA wallets can initialize transactions, and as this logic is hardcoded into the Ethereum protocol, these functionalities can’t be further customized.   twitter.com    Nishil @_nishil_  7/ This is a problem because EOA functionalities are hardcoded into Ethereum protocol and there is no room for customization.  For example: Gmail provides you the option to enable 2FA on your account. Similar customizability can't be done on Ethereum today.   7:12 PM - 10 Oct 2022           11            This limits both users and protocols in a couple of ways:  Unlike smart contract wallets, users can’t use a custom signing schema. Transaction fees must be paid in native ETH.  EIP 4337 aims to incorporate “Account Abstraction” (AA) into the Ethereum protocol without any consensus-layer alterations. AA enables users to utilize smart contract wallets that contain the same verification logic used by EOAs, which (in theory) displaces the need for an EOA wallet entirely. The flow contains three moving parts: User operations, Bundler, and Paymaster.  A technical breakdown is provided in the above link, but at a high level, user operations denotes the logic allowing users to initiate a transaction via a smart contract wallet. Bundlers route these transactions to a global Entry Point, where each user operation is verified by its validation function. The paymaster enables sponsored transactions wherein users could have their transaction fees paid for by a paymaster (likely a protocol).  Why does this matter? For many, it may not – but if the alterations occur without any changes to the consensus layer, users and developers can expect several UX improvements:  Android or iOS schemes could be used to turn a phone into a hardware wallet. It allows for two or more users to approve a single transaction. And per Vitalik, it provides for a “decentralized fee market” for user operations conducted in a smart contract wallet. 2587×570 142 KB  Hi, everyone; thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Whether you hold MKR or DAI, own a vault, or want to get more involved in governance, this is your one-stop shop for MakerDAO updates. Authors: @alec, @nothsa, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon    CURRENT EVENTS   Endgame, Clean Money and Nuclear Energy   This thread sees @rune expand on the Endgame Plan’s goals, motivations, and integrations. Summary of definitions and motivations To begin, the Endgame Plan grew out of the original case for Clean Money, “which focused on the critical importance of “Spark” in DAO governance.” Here, Spark is defined as an individual or team’s drive, interest, and commitment to the DAO and its central purpose.  “It’s the thing that drives individuals to act according to shared community interests rather than their personal [agendas].”  Further, this spark must come from a shared purpose beyond personal enrichment. The DAO’s purpose must extend beyond simple profiteering and the enrichment of its token holders. Similarly, the DAO must also adhere to a purpose that deemphasizes its direct, local, and short-term interests in favor of the shared interests of a much broader group. The challeneges of Clean Money 1.0 summarized The original concept called for Maker to utilize its immense potential for allocating RWA collateral, thus ensuring that climate-aligned investments could make a tangible impact. However, two significant developments altered these initial assumptions:  Political complexity  Initially, the sheer implementation complexity was not yet understood, and attention shifted towards less “complex” and “credit-like” solutions. However, this was still just an attempt to copy and paste existing TradFi processes, and it soon became clear that the design and implementation of entirely new models would be extraordinarily difficult.  Regulatory deterioration   "Secondly, the window of opportunity that would allow Maker to significantly impact the trajectory of crypto regulation closed with the disappointing lack of tangible progress in the last crypto bubble (including Maker’s inability to deliver on Clean Money). Instead of recognition as a promising technology that could help solve humanity’s problems, crypto became further branded as good for nothing other than scams and bubbles, exemplified by the collapse of Terra, Celsius, and 3AC."  Purpose 2.0 The new iteration introduces a more flexible and adaptive model that can “provide purpose and public goods for many different social impact causes, while also boosting the MetaDAOs brands, meta and governance readiness.”  "The first requirement of Clean Money 2.0 is that it must be simple and not get in the way of RWA processes by introducing brand-new concepts or complexity. The second requirement is to prioritize the internal benefits to the meta of the Maker community rather than prioritize influencing regulatory developments. It should, of course, still be seen as an essential factor in proving Maker’s value to society, but this should not be the primary goal.  Proposed solution  A simplified version of Clean Collateral. An example of this comes in the form of ETH and stETH, which – post-merge – are now near carbon neutral.  That said, on its own, carbon neutrality isn’t enough to move the needle. Under the new scope, Maker itself “must use its global scale and powerful economic potential to make its mark in the short-term.” To that end, current geopolitical circumstances grant a unique opportunity to make a meaningful impact without overextending Maker Governance.  “Supporting the advocacy of nuclear power as the completely neglected but most important short-term measure of the sustainable energy transition.”  This, the post posits, is the ideal starting point for “Purpose 2.0”, as it grants MKR holders a narrow scope with minimal complexity to deliver on Clean Money. The full post can be found here or via the above link.*  a16z’s Thoughts on Endgame  Posted by @Porter_Smith, this thread offers a16z’s thoughts on the current state of the Endgame Plan. Summarized commentary The Endgame Plan addresses the need, partly based on political uncertainties, for an optimal organizational design, a long-term growth strategy, and a framework to incentivize internal innovation. A16z feels these debates funnel into one fundamental question: How can we increase MakerDAO’s decentralization while best optimizing long-term growth?  “Given that DAI’s most valuable characteristic is its decentralization, we believe that putting MakerDAO on a long-term path to legal, technical, and economic decentralization through the workforce (legal), the customer (technical), and the product (economic) will provide a strategic direction that can help frame other operational decisions by the community.”  Decentralization summary Porter_Smith believes the Core Unit structure is already (arguably) legally decentralized, as many are wrapped in their LLC, and the managerial efforts of others direct none. Along that vein, the post offers another guiding question.  “…Do we need to externally restructure how Core Units work, per the Endgame Plan, or implement community-driven internal changes to improve accountability, efficiency, and output?”  @Juan’s recent post on project-based budgeting was presented as an example of increasing CU performance without introducing organizational risk. Techincal: Minting DAI summary This section points to @psychonaut’s recent post, Toward decentralized frontend hosting as a means to increase DAI circulation organically.  “For MakerDAO, more technical decentralization practically means “who can enable users access to DAI after depositing collateral?” Or, “how can we incentivize as many access points to DAI generation as possible?” Currently, such frontends exist; however, incentivizing more could lead to more resilient technical decentralization.”  Such incentivization could be achieved through a commission-based model, similar to the strategy deployed by Liquity. Ideally, these schemes would be sufficient in enticing devs to build frontends that offer utility for the multi-chain deployment of DAI, similar to Yearn’s approach. Economic: What backs DAI summarized  “Collateral sits on a spectrum of decentralization, and centralized collateral has inherent risks because it can be frozen or blacklisted by another party. If MakerDAO issues 1B DAI against collateral that is subsequently blacklisted, the system is now insolvent, which is an existential risk to the long-term continuity of the project.”  The post offers three solutions that address this lingering issue:  Only accept “sufficiently decentralized” collateral types, such as Ethereum and certain derivative products. Continue to accept a certain amount of collateral types with centralization risks (USDC, wBTC, etc.) and decrease their usage over time. Embrace that MakerDAO will have to accept some centralized collateral and put caps on it. Over time, any collateral that meets these criteria would have to be backed by the same amount of DAI in the Surplus Buffer.  To conclude, a16z stressed their continued involvement in developing the Endgame Plan.  "The Endgame Plan incorporates different innovations designed to drive MakerDAO forward; we will deliberately evaluate each piece separately through the lenses proposed above. We will support MIPs that we believe will contribute to the decentralization of the protocol. We will vote against MIPs that do not meet this threshold in their current form. We also support experimentation through smaller, self-contained proposals to get a baseline for how proposed changes might work (or not) in practice.  To read the whole post, click here.  Two New MetaDAO Clusters!   Earlier this month, we’ve already witnessed the push toward MetaDAOs with both the Crimson and Viridian clusters proposed for governance approval. Nevertheless, this looks to be the beginning of a potential snowball effect as two more clusters were introduced this week. These are dubious yet exciting times for Maker!   TaiDai Cluster:  Firstly, TaiDai clarifies that its proposal will become formal once Endgame tokens have been distributed and Maker’s governance process is capable of independent decisions. Introduced to you through inspiration and by the creators of Daivinity, TaiDai aims to improve the Maker brand by leveraging events, parties, and the existing relationships built and to-be-built. However, brand awareness also offers opportunities for additional revenue (as we’ve seen from past Daivinity events) that TaiDai is willing to help capitalize on. No longer will we be called the “Boomer Protocol.” It’s time to set the narrative straight and put Maker on top of the hot list. It may not be easy, especially with the complete decentralization of independent clusters; collaboration may be a difficult feat, but TaiDai proposes to utilize the power of strategic alliance by engaging with other MetaDAOs, Maker itself, and web3 partners from around the world. The Daivinity team has already proven itself… but this is just the beginning of a new era   Spring Cluster:  Our fourth Cluster proposal, posted by @Centrifuge and @Blocktower, hit the Forum this week. Dubbed the Spring Cluster, the team aims to “enable the future Protector to build the long-term capability that enables Dai to meet real-world business needs openly and transparently.” The team believes that bringing DAI to the real world is the critical step in its economic success, political acceptance, and its impact on the lives of everyday people and businesses.  "BlockTower, working with Centrifuge, will be the initial arranger within the Protector. Together, we will create repeatable, scalable, and reliable frameworks for on-chain RWA investments. This cluster envisions expanding to include like-minded, technology-driven, impact-focused partners aligned to deliver real-world value promptly and safely. Following the lead taken by Maker Growth in Latin America, this cluster will dedicate time and resources to building out the adoption of Dai in emerging markets, such as Dai investments in Africa, Southeast Asia, and other emerging market countries.  Summary of the proposed mandate  Source, underwrite, structure, and manage deals that protect Maker’s interests, enable Dai’s growth in the real world, and foster the adoption of technologies that make transactions more efficient and open than before. Fully leverage the power of blockchain technology to break through the limitations of existing financial infrastructure.  This can be done by pushing more data on-chain, enabling additional automation via smart contracts, and increasing authenticity through a shared, digital ledger. The Cluster’s general flow would track as follows:  The full proposal can be found here.   Huge thanks to @alec for writing these summaries! 2587×570 581 KB  Hi, everyone; thanks for checking out the Weekly Relay! Whether you hold MKR or DAI, own a vault, or want to get more involved in governance, this is your one-stop shop for MakerDAO updates.  The Weekly Relay is now published Monday mornings! Authors: @alec, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon Online PDF version    CURRENT EVENTS  Endgame Maker’s past few months felt like a microcosm of the global environment. We saw several internal crises, both real and imagined. The governance process underwent radical growth, and its politicization came naturally. This political introduction precipitated a rise in populism. Lines were drawn, and sides were chosen. However, this also led to increased participation in the governance process. With ideals set, proposals were further scrutinized, and the RFC process finally saw the required attention. These efforts were then boiled down into the Endgame MIP Set, and with its passing, the DAO again has a unified purpose. Not everyone will agree with the entirety of this purpose, but viewed piece by piece, the Endgame Plan offers several diverse routes for future growth. To that end, let us explore the many changes enacted by the Endgame Plan - our freshly ratified “collective purpose.”  Endgame Prelaunch MIP Set Passed    Endgame poll totals953×529 25.3 KB  Amassing over 80% of the total votes, the Endgame MIP Set passed with ease. As a result, the following protocol alterations will be enacted:  MIP83: Recognized Launch MetaDAO Clusters   “MIP83 is a part of the Endgame Plan Approval MIP Set configuring the Clusters of the Launch MetaDAOs. This enables groups within the Core Units to begin preparations to restructure as MetaDAOs, a de-risked form of scaling the Decentralized Workforce available in the Endgame.”   MIP84: Activate Protocol-Owned Vault Emulation   “This MIP activates the preliminary implementation of the Protocol-Owned Vault, using the Protocol-Owned Vault Emulation (POVE) approach, which uses a non-standard configuration of the existing Maker Protocol to achieve the effects of a Protocol-Owned Vault.”  With its passing, a Dss-Kiln will be configured and deployed to purchase stETH. An executive will then be crafted to transfer 20M Dai to this new vault.  MIP1c4-SP1: Subproposal for Changing the Problem Space   “MIP1 was largely forgotten and never managed to serve its purpose, but with the Endgame Plan, the same core concept is revived as there needs to be clarity around when Maker Governance starts to slow down and not invite so many proposals.”  Under the above terms, five items would be added to the “Problem Space” - or perceived inefficiencies in the Maker Governance model.   Constitution: The constitution is a MIP that contains the core tenets of the social contract and voter pre-agreements that stabilize the meta of the Endgame State.   Endgame Product MIPs: A set of MIPs that define each Endgame Product in as much detail as possible. Only products already detailed and defined in the Endgame Products MIPs can be added to the Maker Protocol.   Scope MIPs: The Scope MIPs are individual MIPs that each cover the 11 Scopes that define all Maker Governance processes and the expectations and KPIs of the Decentralized Workforce. Metanomics: The Metanomics MIP provides an immutable and unambiguous definition of what the long-run, unchangeable tokenomics of the Endgame State will be. This includes MKR emissions, Maker surplus funneling, MetaDAO emissions, and MetaDAO surplus funneling.   Metanomics: The Metanomics MIP provides an immutable and unambiguous definition of what the long-run, unchangeable tokenomics of the Endgame State will be. This includes MKR emissions, Maker surplus funneling, MetaDAO emissions, and MetaDAO surplus funneling.   Launch MetaDAO Activation: To trigger the Endgame Plan Launch, a Launch MetaDAO Activation MIP is required, as this authorizes the deployment and activation of the MetaDAO tokens and the MetaDAO token farms.    MIP4c4-SP1: MIP Removal Subproposals   “Continuation of the actual useful forms of collateral onboarding is already enabled entirely through the existing governance mandates and their ability to trigger relevant Executive Votes, as specified in MIP16, MIP39, and MIP41, but the Endgame Plan MIP Set also proposes additional amendments to emphasize this existing capability further and ensure that collateral onboarding can continue happening smoothly with no risk of unexpected blockers.”   MIP4c2-SP27: MIP16 Amendment Subproposal   “This MIP is being amended to become compatible with the Endgame Plan and prevent Signal Requests (non-standard weekly polls) from dominating the governance dynamic and acting as a vector for unpredictable complexity growth and governance overhead.” “This MIP Amendment only affects Signal Requests leading to non-standard weekly polls and does not change the standard and primary focus of MIP16.”   MIP39c2-SP35: Modifying Risk Core Unit Mandate - RISK-001   “The updated mandate is written with a new approach where the critical element of the mandate explicitly and directly impacts Facilitator Governance Powers are provided upfront. This information is also described as short and succinct as possible to clarify what Governance Privileges the Core Unit Facilitator will have regarding proposing non-standard weekly polls as defined in MIP16.”   MIP39c2-SP36: Modifying Strategic Finance Core Unit Mandate (SF-001)   “The Strategic Finance Core Unit Mandate is modified as a part of the Endgame Plan Approval MIP Set to eliminate any possible risk of the collateral onboarding process becoming disrupted or blocked by the removal of the old MIP6 process.”   MIP39c2-SP37: Modifying Collateral Engineering Services Core Unit Mandate (CES-001)  Like the SES modification, this MIP aims to eliminate the risk of disrupting or blocking the collateral onboarding process. Details on the proposals can be found here.  Core Units Offboarded - Next Steps  A thread by @Patrick_J documents the following steps to be undertaken in the offboarding of three Core Units: SH-001, EVENTS-001, and RWF-001.  SH-001   Both the DAI and MKR vesting stream will be halted. 43,332 DAI and 26.04 MKR will be sent to the SH-001 multisig.   EVENTS-001   The DAI vesting stream will be halted (there is no MKR vesting stream). 167,666 DAI will be transferred to the EVENTS-001 multisig.   RWF-001   Like EVENTS-001, DAI vesting will be halted, and no MKR vesting stream exists.  However, unlike the previously mentioned offboardings, RWF-001’s budget flow includes an auditor wallet. The offboarding MIP specifies that all payments should be routed through this wallet. After discussions with the auditors from the @SES-Core-Unit, the following will occur:  Zero DAI will be sent from the surplus buffer to the auditor wallet - the auditor wallet has sufficient DAI balance to fund the remaining offboarding costs. Any DAI balance above 176,000 DAI in the auditor wallet will be returned to MakerDAO via DssBlow. 143.46 MKR will be sent to the auditor wallet - this is the approved 201.46 MKR minus the 58 MKR already in the auditor wallet. The auditors will arrange separate MKR payments to team members per the amounts listed in the offboarding proposal.  The full post can be found here.  User Retention Revenue Share, Fixed-Rates, and Decentralized Collateral Scopes  @rune further details the fixed-rate mechanisms and strategy utilized in the increased decentralization of DAI’s collateral backing. These mechanisms only apply to Maker Core Vaults that do not directly support MetaDAO token yield farming.   User retention revenue share bonus   This bonus is based on the observation that long-standing vaults are less likely to be liquidated and would come in addition to the standard 25% stability fee revenue share available to both MetaDAO and “ecosystem actor” frontends. The initial parameters enable a 10% bonus accrued over one year. To help illustrate this accrual:  This means that if a user opens a vault through a MetaDAO frontend and it pays 1000 Dai in stability fees over a period of one year, the MetaDAO gets a total 10% bonus on top of the standard 25% for the entire period, so a total of 35% in revenue share over that one year, for a total of 350 Dai. If a user opens a vault that pays 500 Dai in stability fees over six months before closing, then the MetaDAO gets half of the bonus, so 5%, for a total of 30% for the six months or 150 Dai.    Fixed Rates Module    “The Fixed Rates Module is a conceptual system that allows Maker to target a fixed rates strategy for decentralized assets and its own vaults by using protocols like Deco and other similar products built by fixed rates projects such as Element or Sense.”  Under this model, Decentralized Collateral CUs create a target portfolio based on the information it collects through the Stability and Liquidity Scopes. For example, “a CU might target the accrual of 10% of its total Dai supply locked into term vaults (that the user must pay to wind down early) – and 5% of the total Dai supply into premium fixed rates vault, which can freely wind down early.” The full outline can be found here.   In other news A poll to end DAI funding for SourceCred had passed on October 13th. The last payment for the SourceCred program will be this Friday. However, the instance will continue to calculate cred for users just in case SourceCred is to be used again in the future, but it will not calculate grain, resulting in no DAI tied to the cred.    Shout-outs! Intra-protocol Vault Exposer Migrations Research analysis The Risk team examined vault exposure migrations in a broader context, focusing only on intra-protocol exposure movement. They looked at major collaterals such as ETH, stETH, and WBTC. According to the analysis, intra-protocol migrations are not common since most vault owners tend to keep to vaults that offer better borrowing conditions (e.g., lower liquidation risk). Though the exact reasons are unknown, the team believes the rationale is that users are more cautious during bear market conditions. The Risk team hopes to investigate cross-protocol migration in the future. See the report for a complete breakdown! Multiparty Democracy in Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO): Evidence from MakerDAO Research paper A group of researchers consisting of Ph.D. student Xiaotong Sun, associate professor Xi Chen, professor Charalampos Stasinakis, and professor Georgios Sermpinis attempt to answer the controversial question: can blockchain technology help to achieve decentralized governance? Using actual governance data from MakerDAO, they examine whether DAO governance is a multiparty democracy and how voting parties affect DeFi protocols. Authors: @alec, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon Online PDF version    CURRENT EVENTS  Last week’s G&R Call saw two proposed Clusters further detail their overarching schemas: Crimson and Viridian. A summarized breakdown of each Q&A segment will follow.  Crimson Cluster  Cluster presentation here.  2285×1284 176 KB  “What is Crimson’s cash-flow generation, and how does it incorporate into the metaDAO token?” Per @hexonaut, Crimson’s inaugural release will be a high-efficiency lending front-end. Initially, cash flow generates from this lending engine in the form of interest rates.  Much like Maker Vaults, users can deposit digital assets to borrow DAI (with an attached Stability Fee). Further premiums are collected from users “borrowing” this lent collateral.  These collected fees would then be dispersed between LPs and the metaDAO. “Do you plan on using the D3M for RWA platforms?” Crimson is not currently focused on RWAs, but rather on DeFi-native assets. “Will Crimson have on-chain governance?” Yes, the metaToken will function as the platform’s governance token. “What are some potential competitors, and how is this Cluster better?” Listed Competitors: Aave, Compound, Oiler Finance. hexonaut believes Crimson possesses two niche advantages:  The platform focuses on significant assets (i.e., BTC, ETH, and staked ETH derivatives) and will not be competing for tail-end assets. All other lending markets utilize Chainlink oracles. Initially, Crimson will instead use Maker Oracles, but the ultimate vision remains a multi-oracle system, utilizing both Chainlink and Maker Oracles.  “Are you planning on having algorithmic rates?” Stables can be borrowed at fixed rates in quantities not exceeding the current debt ceiling. @hexonaut sees these fixed rates as an integral part of the platform’s draw. “Users don’t like taking leveraged positions on platforms with volatile lending rates that can spike at any time, so [Crimson] prefers the Maker model for stablecoin borrowing.” The full interview can be found here, or through the above link.  Viridian Cluster  Cluster presentation here.  2354×1267 230 KB  “How is your cluster thinking about the possibility of “risk-on” partnerships with arrangers that go after riskier opportunities?” Per @Allan_Pedersen, the idea is to generate maximum yield, but many of the strat-gems depend on the “hard frameworks” Maker develops to expand RWAs. “Do you see any opportunities in the short-to-medium term with Corporates?” Viridian currently operates “risk on,” and the current governance process moves too slowly to undertake these risks in the current climate. The team does see an opportunity here, but they might not be ideal for Maker as situated. “How do you plan on hedging Risk for RMBS when exposed to it through arrangers?” Because these bonds are bought below “par,” Viridian should capture additional yield. This would typically create additional risks as this inflow is reinvested, but the team doesn’t expect to sustain losses on this yield as Viridian’s cash flow is sufficiently compressed. “In the current environment, why not just go all in on treasuries and earn over 4% with minimal risk?” Per @SebVentures, the team has considered re-investing its short-term bonds, but to do so through DeFi instruments presents a problem. “At some point, we have to give some of this cash flow to DAI holders by increasing the DSR.” To receive a 4% yield “risk-free,” the allocated stables would need to be arbitraged. Using DeFi products for this process, much of this yield would be lost to slippage and arbitrageurs. Placed alongside any DSR increases, the overall spread would be very narrow. “Is the Viridian Cluster responsible for the risk and legal assessments of its RWA deals?” Per Allan_Pedersen, the team hopes to provide stand-alone risk and legal assessments regarding “direct counterparties” (i.e., Monetalis and any future arranges ratified through governance). The full discussion can be found here, or via the link in the title.    Shout-outs!  Drinks with Delegates ft. Moreover, the trio shared their opinions and possible implications for reactivating the DSR as federal interest rates continue to rise. This idea originated in the governance channel. However, the drinks were not finished that soon; Further discussions focused on the Target Rate Feedback Mechanism and the DeFi Collateral Problem. Authors: @alec, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon Online PDF version    CURRENT EVENTS  In the 1940s, Maj. Edward J. Murphy led the US Air Force’s team for developmental engineering. Given that his team worked at the intersection between theory and practice, they frequently faced unexpected results. As they continued to break new ground, they found that all the tried-and-tested models to ensure precision could have been more effective. Instead, they relied on initiative and intuition. From this team came Murphy’s Law, which states that whatever can go wrong will. Crypto operates in a similar space. No models define correctness, and no compass offers guidance, so when things go wrong - they often go wrong in unexpected ways. The need for continued, focused engagement and innovation has never been clearer in this unforgiving environment. Fortunately, this week saw numerous efforts to define Maker’s path and position better.  Discussion on Enabling the DSR  @SebVentures, in tandem with the MakerDAO Open Market Committee (MOMC), proposes an increase to the DAI Savings Rate (DSR). Summary of motivations  “Given that MIP65, the GUSD partnership, and soon MIP81 will give us access to TradFi safe yield or rewards, we have all the tools to generate sustainable revenues at scale.”  This proposal comes as a double-edged sword of sorts. A DSR increase improves DAI’s utility but comes at a high up-front cost to the DAO.  Per Seb, in TradFi, the “risk-free” benchmark currently stands at 3.8%. The Coinbase deal offers 1.5%, but its custodial nature has caused significant friction As it currently stands, DAI offers a meager 0.01%.  Summary of the opportunity Both Compound and Aave have an in-built DSR integration currently left inactive. Assuming a 2% DSR, the lending rate on Compound would move from 1.2% to 2.25% - over double USDC’s current rate. The team feels this incentivizes USDC holders to migrate to DAI, improving its positioning on leading lending engines. Further, the DAO could bolster its DEX liquidity through CHAI (an ERC-20 token built atop the DSR), which could be paired with stable-ETH LPs.  Urgent Collateral Parameter Changes!  In light of the recent market drawbacks, @Primoz posted an Urgent Signal seeking community sentiment on several parameter changes. If passed, the following alterations would be enacted:   Decrease MATIC-A Debt Ceiling from current 20M to 10M  Decrease LINK-A Debt Ceiling from current 25M to 5M  Decrease YFI-A Debt Ceiling from current 10M to 3M  Decrease renBTC-A Debt Ceiling from current 10M to 0  Of these assets, renBTC has the highest “tail risk asset” due to uncertainties surrounding its post-FTX market positioning. The Signal also aims to proceed with the proposed MANA parameter changes despite action from the borrower. If passed, MANA’s parameters would be adjusted as follows:  Decrease Debt Ceiling to 3M from the current 10M (pending current executive vote execution) Significantly increase SF to 50% from the current 7.5% (pending current executive vote execution) Increase liquidation penalty to 30% from the current 13%  The Signal concluded with a 75% ‘Yes’ vote, and thus, will be included in an out-of-schedule Executive. The full thread can be found here. Authors: @alec, @Sol_Invictus, and @Artem_Gordon Online PDF version    CURRENT EVENTS   Endgame Plan next steps: 2023 milestones for MetaDAO Launch  With the approval of the Endgame MIP Set, the “Pregame” phase is officially underway. This post saw @rune expand on what to expect in 2023. Summary of 2023 MetaDAO Milestones:  1) Pregame Product smart contracts  These are the contracts necessary to launch the on-chain components of future MetaDAOs.   EtherDai token wrapper deployment Elixir Balancer pool deployment MetaDAO ERC20 token deployments (one for each MetaDAO) Meta Elixir Uniswap v2 pool deployments (one for each MetaDAO) Anti-Reflexivity Mechanic deployments (one for each MetaDAO)  Linear token sales mechanism to prevent price spikes   Dai Farms (one for each MetaDAO) EtherDai Farms (one for each MetaDAO) MKR Farms (one for each MetaDAO)  Metanomics I deployment  70,000 MKR emitted per year, with 60000 funneled directly to the Meta Elixir of each of the MetaDAOs   Various dss-kiln and proxy contract deployments to manage accounts and token flows for MetaDAOs    “Of these features, I believe that the ETHD Farms and the MKR farms are the only ones that are somewhat technically challenging in terms of new code required, while the rest is almost all extremely simple code and implementation.”   2) MVP of the MetaDAO frontends  Per the post, a MetaDAO – like any DeFi protocol – is defined by its front end, so it’s imperative to have quality UIs in place for these initial Launch MetaDAOs. These frontends will require the following:   Access to all Dai Farms Access to opening Maker Vaults (including EtherDai Vaults) Access to all EtherDai Vault Farms Access to all MKR Farms MVP of the Easy Voter Frontend that is required for users who wish to farm with MKR, as they need to first delegate through this frontend to be able to farm with MKR Support for MetaDAOs adding their products or external services.    3) The MetaDAO Cluster journey  Steps that must be met before the launch of a MetaDAO:   Cluster announcements Vote to include announced Clusters as Recognized Launch MetaDAO Clusters Creation of MetaDAO forums Early meta development of the new MetaDAO forums Approval of the starting MIP-like infrastructure of new MetaDAOs by Maker Governance Preparation of MIP39-equivalent onboarding proposals by the Clusters to a specific MetaDAO each Launch of the MetaDAO frontends and the Pregame Smart contracts, which begins the distribution of MetaDAO tokens to Dai, ETHD, and MKR holders Onboarding of the Clusters as Administration Teams to each of the MetaDAOs Normal operation of the MetaDAOs with Administration Teams in charge of running their governance processes and facilitating budgets and community decisions.    4) The Endgame Constitution and the Endgame Scope Frameworks   "The Constitution and Scope Frameworks will be the primary way that the processes of Maker Governance itself will be locked down to prevent corruption or instability of direction over time. The constitution will govern eligibility for compensation from Maker Core as a Mandated Actor, Recognized Delegate, or Recognized Decentralized Voter Committee."  The utilized Endgame Scope Frameworks will be defined in the constitution, making them difficult to change, add, or remove. These carefully designed frameworks are then used for “all lower-level decisions surrounding the implementation or actions of the Decentralized Workforce, MetaDAOs and Ecosystem Actors, and any compensation-based risk parameter adjustments.” The post concludes by stating that each of the above items must be completed by the end of 2023 to ensure that the Endgame Plan remains on track. Click here to read the post in its entirety.   Gasless Voting is Here!      You can now submit your vote preferences at zero cost through the voting portal frontend! Summary of the process:   Gasless voting is the default option unless a user specifies a preference for a legacy (L1) transaction. This is accomplished through a relay service that securely submits vote metadata to a polling contract hosted on Arbitrum. The Governance database listens to the event and appends it to the table. When requested by the front end, votes from both networks are merged and calculated. The frontend UI displays the merged polling results.    2880×1664 231 KB  The system also features numerous Spam Protection Checks   Address has at least 0.1 MKR of poll voting weight. Address has not used the Gasless Poll Voting system in the last 10 minutes. Address has only voted once in any of the polls included in the ballot. Address is not a multisig wallet. (note: Safe multisigs do not yet support off-chain message signing)   For a video walk-through of the gasless voting process, Click here, or for a detailed technical overview - head to the Maker Operational Manual. Authors: @Sol_Invictus and @Artem_Gordon Online PDF version    CURRENT EVENTS   Dai Savings Rate Increased to 1%   The community and our recognized delegates voted to increase Dai’s annual reward to 1.00%. Due to current market conditions, yields in DeFi continue to fall and decrease demand for loans, especially since traditional market yields have skyrocketed. This has pushed more users out of decentralized stablecoins like Dai and into USD. A higher DSR (Dai Savings Rate) encourages users to hold more Dai, which leads to higher demand and liquidity. Even though a DSR of 1% is far below the traditional market yield, this represents a significant improvement to MakerDAO’s protocol revenue. However, sustaining a higher DSR involves more maintenance and costs; we must ensure sufficient liquidity in order to maintain Dai stability, and the total cost of maintaining Dai stability increased to 12,000 Dai. This cost would significantly increase if the Dai supply deposited into the PSM also increases, however at a benefit:  ‘Higher DSR rates would significantly increase Maker’s cost base but may be more than compensated for by improved revenue generating capacity.’ - MOMC  The passing of this poll opens opportunities for more partnership integrations and increased user retention. Dai is now a more competitive stablecoin . Please refer to this documentation and discussion post for more information about the Dai Savings Rate. MIPs for the Scope Framework is split into three components:  Content (replaces MIPs on processes and procedures in the DAO). Budget (replaces the Core Unit MIP structure). Future Implementation (replaces Declaration of Intent MIP). Until now… Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST) enters the arena as Maker’s newest Recognized Delegate with the following Core Values to drive their platform. HKUST EPI aims to present value to the protocol by:  Establishing a beneficial and friendly environment between Universities and Protocols. Developing innovative solutions through critical thinking. Educating the next generation about the benefits of blockchain technology in TradeFi. Supporting the protocol on Treasury, Budgeting, Process Streamlining, and Collateral Risk Management. And sharing their insights, industry knowledge, and experiences.   Summary of Delegate Statement  HKUST openly embraces the visions and innovation stemming from bleeding-edge technologies, and its students are actively encouraged to explore these new frontiers.  "As blockchain technology is still maturing and adoption rapidly increases, continuous education and development should be established. Strategic planning, proper decision-making, and marketing are required for mainstream adoption to be achieved. Therefore, establishing a research lab (EPI) to synergize the growth of MakerDAO, by governance participation, with exposure to blockchain technology and decentralized finance, would provide a mutually beneficial symbiotic relationship between MakerDAO and the University."  The delegator will be led by a University researcher, with volunteer students filling out the Research Lab. This Lab expects to be fully vested in Maker Governance, with frequent and timely communication on all governance decisions. The Lab will receive assistance from other Faculty members on topics such as Research, Education, Business Development, and Web3-centric developments. Focus will be placed on several initiatives, including:  Actively participating in forum discussions. Initiating new improvement proposals. Monitoring protocol news and updates. Seeking consultations with respective faculty members or with collaborating external parties. Communicating with internal team members. And offering public Q&A with their delegators.  Curious to learn more? Join the next Meet Your Delegate call happening this Wednesday at 5:30 p.m. UTC, where EPI Lab will present their platform and answer all of your questions.   Uncertain Paths as Core Unit Budgets are Rejected Several Core Units had their budgets rejected, with delegates advising transitions to Endgame-compliant positions as Ecosystem Actors. Governance Communications, Immunifi Security, SideStream Auction Services, and TechOps all had their budgets rejected during the November governance cycle. The rejections did not come with any offboarding proposals but rather left the Core Units in a questionable position, asking them to figure out their next move. Each group scrambled to understand what to do next. Over the last week, we saw proposals published, hinting at these teams’ future. Some Core Units are anxious to see how delegates will vote during the next round of budget proposals coming in March. Hopes for a smooth transition into Endgame are dwindling.  Governance Communications  COM-001 Unwinding GovComms was the first to act, proposing their own offboarding with no certain future in mind. Following the budget rejection, GovComms worked with GovAlpha Core Unit to transition the critical and most valuable parts of their work. They are on track to close everything out by the end of January. The proposal generated a range of responses. Many expressed gratitude and well wishes, while others felt confusion and uncertainty. However, the bulk of the discussion focused on the golden parachute and retroactive MKR compensation.  Debate on Golden Parachute and Retroactive Compensation The offboarding proposal that polled for the level of retroactive MKR compensation sparked some lively discussion on the fairness of the proposal with regards to the golden parachute and retroactive MKR compensation. While many agree on the general concept of the golden parachute, the disagreements stemmed from the questions of “How much should the DAO compensate offboarded units?” and “is the level of retroactive MKR compensation fair?” One side argued that the packages might be too generous, while others argued that compared to other Core Units, GovComms was being penalized for poor timing and that they should be compensated on a comparable level.  Immunifi Security  Mandate and Budget Rejected Besides their budget, Immunefi Security also had its mandate rejected as delegates generally agreed about the value of the bug bounty program, but stated that the Core Unit should transition to an Ecosystem Actor and that they wouldn’t support the revised mandate.  IS as an Ecosystem Actor The Deputy Facilitator, Psychonaut, committed to moving forward as an Ecosystem actor, but requested more time to transition. A proposal for bridge funding was posted. In parallel, recognized delegate Flipside Crypto posted a formal offboarding proposal for the Core Unit.  Sidestream Auction Services  Budget Rejected SAS had its budget rejected as delegates expressed their opinions that the services provided by Sidestream may be better offered as an Ecosystem Actor.  SAS as an Ecosystem Actor Sidestream requested bridge funding to finance operations until March 2023. The team has acknowledged the feedback provided by Delegates and will wind down auction-related work to a bare minimum by only maintaining current auction services. During the next few months, they will work on a process to support Endgame products as a software service provider. Recognized Delegate Flipside Crypto posted a formal offboarding proposal for the Core Unit.  TechOps  Budget Rejected TechOps had its budget rejected as delegates believe that the Core Unit should reduce its budget and transition as an Ecosystem Actor or Tribunal.  New Budget as an Ecosystem Actor/Infrastructure Tribunal TechOps requested bridge funding through February 2023 as they propose a new budget they hope will win favor with delegates, which offers even lower Base and Bear options. Along with this, TechOps will transition as either an Ecosystem Actor or Infrastructure Tribunal and update its roadmap to include these as new objectives. If passed, this new budget proposal will begin on April 1st, 2023.   Compound v2 D3M Integrated The long awaited executive vote to integrate D3M with Compound has officially passed!  The community showed overwhelming support to onboard a second D3M, as it’s been over a year since the first one with Aave. D3Ms help position DAI as a more liquid and convenient stablecoin to borrow. Compound users can now benefit from a fixed DAI borrowing rate, which is an attractive option within the volatile structure of DeFi. Compound V2 D3M Vault Parameters:  Maximum Debt Ceiling: 5 million DAI. Target Available Debt: 5 million DAI. Ceiling Increase Cooldown (ttl): 12 hours. Target Borrow Rate (bar): 2%.
