Authors: @alec, @Artem_Gordon, and @Sol_Invictus Online PDF version   Happy Holidays and Farewell   First and foremost, we wish everyone a very merry and happy holiday season. Hopefully, you all had a fantastic year filled with knowledge, excitement, and experience. The most important thing we hope for next year is that MakerDAO and its community will be able to realize the Endgame Phase and that Santa Claus will bring a bull market sooner rather than later.  Now for the sad news: Since GovComms has been offboarded, these publications have come to an unfortunate end. It was a pleasure to have the opportunity to provide our readers with weekly recaps, event summaries, and news updates. However, do not fret just yet! Wipe those tears away because we do not wish this opportunity to be wasted. In accordance with the Endgame transition, I (Artem Gordon) am in the process of reorganizing a new and improved publication service. While I do not want to reveal any surprises, expect the Relay and Forum Recaps to come back bigger and better than ever (along with a few new twists and unique improvements). Watch for the official announcement and discussion posts soon after the ball drops.  image1200×627 210 KB     CURRENT EVENTS   Open Decentralized Voter Committee – “The Endgame Constitution”  Rune breaks down the latest iteration of the Endgame Roadmap, listed below. It’s emphasized that the majority of these lack tangible content. This Open DVC, instead, served to introduce these terms as well as outline their relation to the Endgame Constitution.   1644×782 86.5 KB   Summary of intentions: Rune feels we need to “rethink” what we’ve, to date, been calling the Endgame Plan. Strip away the interlacing complexity of each moving piece, and “what’s left is the Endgame Constitution.” This Constitution serves to elevate the Endgame’s many pieces from abstract concepts to concrete plans of action. In other words, it encapsulates the entirety of the Endgame Plan, including the interactions between each element.  “The whole Plan, then, naturally grows from the Consitution. Like a single MIP that implements everything, it’s fundamentally responsible for implementing these mechanisms that self-reinforce and resist change.”  Summary of discussed terms: The goal is a document akin to the U.S. Constitution, complete with an artistic flourish of the era, lending an air of professionalism that’s missed in modern implementations.  The Principles of the Endgame Constitution are ideals, set in stone, “that each voter must understand to [better utilize] the mechanisms of the Constitution.”   “If you have no voters that understand, follow, and act based on these guiding principles – the Endgame fails. However, the system only needs a few to maintain its effectiveness. …These voters assure the system remains stable in the face of any of the [many] risks that we now know exist.”   Preserving the purpose and meta of Maker and DAO  This step requires MKR holders that act based on something greater than simple personal gain. This is a natural extension of the above “principles” dictating the DAO’s overarching direction. These initial items dictate the “rules of operation” for proceeding terms. For example, the DAOs principles and purpose drive the function of its metaDAOs. Per Rune, the most critical of these comes in an easy-to-use voting front-end. This front end comes equipped with a Delegate ranking system based on “popularity” (i.e., vote weight). This UI requires consistent engagement to retain this top slot and the visibility that comes with it. In that sense, this UI “self-polices” participation and fits on the delegate end while streamlining the selection process on the user side. The role of SubDAOs summarized: While these units may engage in independent projects, Governance SubDAOs assume the de-facto title of Mandated Actor. As in the current system, these protocol actors can be “penalized for any failings to follow the ratified Constitution.”  “[The system] assumes everyone to be corrupt, as very few MKR holders are actual semi-altruists.”  As such, this penalization system must be clearly defined at each step, leaving no doubt about the consequences of a particular transgression. The goal is to comprehensively codify the process, allowing the protocol to wage these penalties automatically. This better aligns with the decentralized ethos and allows the workforce to fully anonymize over time. Timeline summarized:  The current task list is filled with unknowns. By the end of Q1, these unknowns will be fully explored, dissected, and quantified. Q2, we’ll see these processes formally ratified, with all DVC Subcommittee calls operating as defined in this Constitution. After further, now informed, updates to the Constitution, a Q3 launch of SubDAOs is expected. In Q4, everything learned and implemented will be ossified or fixed, and the DAO can begin to fully operate under the rules of engagement formalized in the Constitution.  Community Discussion: While community conversation is confined and brief, some dissent was expressed. @LongForWisdom questioned the scope and complexity of an all-encompassing Constitution and offered an alternative structure.  “The aim of a constitution in my mind is to be a short, easily understandable document that explains what Maker is trying to achieve, why, and how it plans to do so at a high level.”  This proposed structure:  Includes articles 1-3 in your division above. Defines enshrined legislation (and the requirements for changing it) Includes a list of enshrined legislation. Defines mutable legislation (and the requirements for changing it) Includes a list of mutable legislation. A clear statement that the constitution itself is enshrined, meaning no one can add additional mutable legislation without clearing the enshrined modification requirement. A set of enshrined legislation as defined in the constitution but not part of it. These are MIP-like documents covering what you currently define as articles 4-10. I’d recommend that they be MIPs and that you re-purpose the MIPs framework to host these and nothing else. But MIP-like is fine. A set of mutable legislation (i.e., the scope contents).   “This keeps complex information separated into digestible chunks and allows us to go into the required level of detail without polluting the constitution with the sort of legal crap you need to constrain the actions of profit-seeking entities effectively.”  A link to the complete video discussion can be found here, or to read the accompanying post in its entirety – click here. Watch the entire presentation here on the Know Your MIP call hosted by Retro and Juan.  MIP13c3-SP13: Declaration of Intent to Develop a Comprehensive On-chain Monitoring Solution for RWA Vaults  Proposed by Recognized Delegates @rspa and @twblack88, our newest MIP calls for developing an on-chain monitoring system for RWA Vaults. Summary of context and motivations:  “Current RWA monitoring is lagging behind as much as 13 months in the case of New Silver”  After ratifying several RWA-centric MIPs via the Endgame MIP Set, it’s clear that the DAO aims to scale these RWA Vaults to capture “safe” and diversified yield. As such, each step of this process must offer full transparency. Currently, no CU is “explicitly and directly” responsible for monitoring RWAs, though SF-001 plans to offer a set of viable solutions. The proposal notes that these efforts were conducted as an extension of the team’s current mandate and came attached with considerable extra costs. Summary of Community response: Per @Aes, SF-001 is currently in the process of onboarding to develop and report on existing RWA collateral types.  “Given MakerDAO’s significant expansion in RWAs and the fact that a majority of protocol income is derived from RWAs, we believe it is critical that these assets are monitored, reported on, and transparency around these assets given the off-chain nature and complexity is provided to the community in a digestible format.”  Rspa believes the desired solution has three tiers: 1. Data Intake Under this system, the DAO requires trusted, capable third-party accountants to monitor cash flow and funnel that data into the middleware infrastructure. 2. Middleware - Infrastructure This middleware would ideally be an oracle. Chainlink’s Proof-of-Reserve is currently being strongly considered barring further community input. 3. Representation  “Representation is more than [its] UX.”  Ideally, this data would be curated to enable vault health to be quickly checked while providing granular breakdowns for those wishing to dive further. Last week’s G&R call contained a live discussion on RWA management approaches toward due diligence, maintenance, and monitoring. SF-001 first relays why such a solution is required:  “If you’re an MKR holder or a metaDAO, you could direct funds to yourself. There’s no law against it; particularly as an MKR holder, there’s no one to stop you. So, this needs to be designed into the system itself to ensure that it’s either very obvious or just not possible when this occurs.” - G&R Ep. 21 (39:38)  Another pressing topic was Oracle’s choice, namely, would Maker Oracles be utilized? Per @nikKunkel, RWA deals currently have no standardized template. Each implementation requires custom tailoring and unique parameters that make the operation too difficult to scale. In response, @rspa offers an interesting solution:  “In the future, perhaps RWA collateral should be chosen by the ability to monitor it easily. With crypto collateral, we’re pretty choosy. We should apply the same discretion in the real world.”   MIP90: Liquid AAA Strictured Credit & Money Market Fund  Under this MIP, a 600M DAI vault would be opened to acquire USDC via the PSM to purchase diversified AAA – or equivalent – investment vehicles.  At the end of each quarter, collected interest would be remitted to the DAO and used to bolster the Surplus Buffer.  Principal proceeds, or the sum of all the funds made available to the issuer, excluding accrued interest, would be reinvested until “liquidation is triggered through governance.”     Calls, Meetings, and Events   Visit: Calls Calendar  Last Week’s Calls   Meet Your Delegate #22 | HKUST EPI Blockchain – Wednesday, December 14th, 2022   Video / Forum / Platform     Know Your MIP #16 | MIP92: Onboard PSM USDC to Yearn to earn yield – Wednesday, December 14th, 2022   Video / Forum  Check G&R #218 for an overview of MIP92 by @corn, its author.
